subsection.heading: 1 Introduction
subsection.p: All Romance languages have a reflexive-reciprocal clitic (se in French, Spanish, and Romanian, and si in Italian, referred to as SE henceforth). In most Romance languages, Goal/Benefactive reflexives are formally indistinguishable from Theme/Patient reflexives. In Romanian, however, Goal/Benefactive reflexive clitics are overtly marked for dative Case (îşiDat vs. seAccus). Certain Romance languages – for example, Italian, Spanish, and Portuguese (but not French or Romanian) – also have a nominative/subject SE (best translated as ‘one’ in English and ‘on’ in French).

The terms ‘accusative, dative, and nominative’ SE may seem somewhat surprising insofar as these three elements show no overt morphological distinctions (with the exception of Romanian dative SE). This terminology is nevertheless justified by the possibility of analyzing the three types of SE as differing with respect to abstract Case. Assuming that a given abstract Case can be assigned to only one element (or chain) inside the same syntactic domain, it is possible to infer the abstract Case of SE on the basis of the Cases of the other DPs with which SE co-occurs: thus, accusative SE may co-exist with nominative or dative DPs, but not with accusative DPs; nominative SE may co-exist with accusative DPs; etc. The abstract Case distinctions correlate with functional distinctions only partially: nominative SE can indeed be analyzed as an arbitrary subject clitic, but accusative SE cannot be said to be an object clitic, because (i) reflexives built with accusative SE do not behave as transitives (see section 2.1.3.1) and (ii) accusative SEs other than reflexives (inherent, inchoative, passive, or middle SE) cannot even be assumed to correspond to (suppressed) arguments. Finally, theta-role distinctions are also only partially helpful: we can indeed distinguish between accusative and dative reflexive-reciprocals in terms of theta-roles (Theme/Patient vs. Goal/Benefactive), but theta-roles are irrelevant for distinguishing between accusative and dative inherent SE-verbs.

Dative and nominative SE will occupy only very few pages of this chapter (see sections 2.2 and 2.3, respectively). Starting with section 3, we will focus on accusative SE, and more particularly on its middle and passive readings. How many accusative SEs are there? What is the common feature or structure that underlies its various readings (reflexive, passive, middle, inchoative, inherent)? Is it possible to propose a unifying analysis or should we postulate several homophonous types of accusative SE?

There are many phenomena regarding se/si in Romance that will be left aside: (i) the intricate detail of the placement of SE in French and Italian causatives and Italian restructuring environments; (ii) the various semantic constraints on the features of the implicit Agent in passive SE configurations; and (iii) long-distance bound reflexives in Italian. 1

subsection.heading: 2 Types of SE
subsection.p: The overview below is meant to illustrate the main contexts in which accusative, dative, and nominative SE can each be found.

subsection.heading: 2.1 Accusative SE
subsection.p: According to some GB theorists of the 1980s, reflexive, middle, and passive SE are intrinsically distinct elements (Belletti 1982; Grimshaw 1982; Zubizarreta 1987; Cinque 1988; among many others). 2 This view cannot explain why these elements systematically exhibit the same morphological form across Romance languages. 3

Partial unification of the various readings of accusative SE goes back to Burzio (1986): inchoative, inherent, middle, and passive SEs are alike insofar as they can all be analyzed as markers of unaccusativity, 4 understood as a lexical operation that triggers the suspension of the external theta-role and of accusative Case.

Interesting evidence due to Kayne (1975), Burzio (1986), and Pesetsky (1995) suggests that the unaccusative analysis can be extended to reflexive SE. This hypothesis has been convincingly criticized by Reinhart and Siloni (2004), who argue instead that reflexive SE-verbs behave as unergatives.

subsection.heading: 2.1.1 Inherent and inchoative SE
subsection.p: Inherent and inchoative SE-verbs are two subclasses of unaccusatives (overt Theme, no explicit or implicit Agent), which differ from each other by the absence vs. presence of transitive alternates: inchoatives have transitive alternates, whereas ‘inherent SE-verbs’ do not; they are of necessity accompanied by SE, and are registered as such in the Lexicon:

(1)
a. Inherent:
Marie s’est évanouie.
Mary SE has fainted. 5
‘Mary fainted.’
b. Inchoative:
La branchei si’est cassée ei.
the branch SE has broken
‘The branch broke.’

Building on earlier insights by Zribi-Hertz (1987), Labelle (1992) has established that French inchoatives built with SE (e.g., s’agrandir ‘to get bigger, to enlarge’) behave as unaccusatives, whereas those inchoatives that cannot be constructed with SE (e.g., cuire ‘to cook’) qualify as unergatives. The distinction was clearly established on the basis of tests such as auxiliary selection, il-impersonals and en-extraction, embedded infinitival relatives, tough-constructions, adjectival passives, and participial constructions.

The question now arises as to what determines – for a given change-of-state verb – the choice between functioning as an unaccusative (in which case it is marked with SE) or as an unergative (in which case SE is precluded). Following Rothemberg (1974), Bernard (1971), Burston (1979), and Forest (1988), the answer proposed by Labelle is that the unergative form is used with predicates that express internally driven, autonomous natural processes 6 (vieillir, maigrir, grandir, grossir, rougir, sécher, pâlir, fondre, cuire, durcir, éclater ‘to grow old, thin, tall, fat, to go red in the face, to dry, to pale, to melt, to cook, to harden, to burst’). The processes described by these verbs may be brought about by external causes expressed by complements introduced by de, but such causes only constitute the initial force that induces an internally caused process. Even if such external causes are mentioned, these verbs do not allow SE: (*se) rougir de honte, (*se) fondre sous l’effet de la chaleur ‘(*se) go red with shame, (*se) melt with the heat’.

Many inchoative verbs – more precisely, those that may refer to natural processes as unfolding in an autonomous way (although not internally caused) – allow both constructions, with notable aspectual differences: casser/se casser ‘break’, raffraîchir/se raffraîchir ‘cool off’, durcir/se durcir ‘harden’. In the SE-construction, the object undergoing the change of state is projected to the object position, and consequently it is used as an event-measure in the sense of Tenny (1987). Correlatively, SE-inchoatives focus on the final state of the entity undergoing the change, rather than on the unfolding of the process itself. 7 This characterization of the difference between unergative and unaccusative inchoatives constitutes a refinement of Zribi-Hertz's (1987) claim that reflexive inchoatives are perfective or resultative. This generalization has been questioned by Lagae (1990), who argues that the focus on the final state that indeed characterizes SE-inchoatives is not to be analyzed as perfectivity, although it does explain certain restrictions on the choice of tense or the incompatibility with certain aspectual markers, e.g., mettre le vin à raffraîchir/*se raffraîchir ‘let the wine cool’.

SE is obligatorily used whenever an external cause is implied. It is particularly striking that verbs built with causative prefixes such as a- or en-, or causative suffixes like -ifier- or -iser, require SE: s’alléger ‘become lighter’, s’agrandir ‘to grow bigger’, s’assécher ‘to dry out’, s’amaigrir ‘to become thinner’, s’abêtir ‘become stupid’, s’allourdir ‘to become heavier’, se diversifier ‘to diversify’, s’humidifier ‘to become humid’.

There exist some verbs which, although they are not morphologically complex, require SE in order to take the inchoative reading. According to Labelle, such verbs are to be classified as “conceptually transitive,” i.e., as requiring both their arguments to be projected, unless the external argument is absorbed by SE. A case in point is provided by the pair briser/casser ‘break’, which are near-synonyms, but differ regarding the use of SE: in the absence of SE, casser can be used both as a transitive and as an inchoative, whereas briser is of necessity transitive; its inchoative use requires SE. The existence of pairs of verbs such as briser/casser indicates that the choice between the unaccusative and unergative status may sometimes be idiosyncratic, unmotivated. This leads us to expect that the choice between SE-marking and unmarked forms for semantically close verbs may differ from one Romance language to another. Although detailed analyses exist for most Romance languages (see in particular Folli 2002a, 2002b and Masullo 1999 for Italian and Spanish, respectively), there is no comparative study of this domain of the grammar.

subsection.heading: 2.1.2 Middle and passive SE
subsection.p: Middle SE and passive SE are alike regarding thematic structure (the overt DP is a Theme, and the Agent is either implicit or realized as an Adjunct by-phrase), but differ insofar as middles are interpreted generically, as ascribing a property to the subject DP, whereas passives refer to (particular or habitual) events:

(2)
a. Middle:
Le greci sei traduit ei facilement.
the Greek SE translates easily
‘Greek translates easily.’
b. Eventive passive:
Ilj si’est traduit trois romansi.
it SE has translated three novels
‘Three novels were translated.’
c. Habitual passive:
Les pommes se mangent en hiver.
apples SE eat during winter
‘Apples are eaten during winter.’

Much of the literature devoted to SE has focused on various issues relating to the analysis of middle and passive SE: (i) the syntactic representation of the implicit Agent; (ii) the distribution of middle and passive SE in Italian non-finite clauses; and (iii) the correlation between the position of the subject and the reading of SE-verbs. Sections 3, 4, and 5 below are devoted to these issues respectively.

subsection.heading: 2.1.3 Reflexive-reciprocal SE
subsection.p: (3a–b) illustrate the reflexive and reciprocal uses of SE-verbs:

(3)
a. Jeani sei lave ei.
John SE washes
‘John washes himself.’
b. Jean et Marie se disputent souvent.
John and Mary SE quarrel frequently

Insofar as they alternate with object clitics, reflexive and reciprocal SEs seem to have pronominal status; hence Kayne's (1975) rule of SE-placement, which leaves behind a trace of SE in an A-position. Kayne clearly showed, however, that SE-placement differs from Cl(itic)-placement (the rule that moves pronominal clitics from an A-position to a clitic position; see chapter 13) in crucial ways. Further evidence going in the same direction led Burzio (1986: 42) to the conclusion that reflexive SE is ambiguous between an object clitic and a marker of unaccusativity (“affix[es] with no other syntactic function than marking the lack of theta-role assignment to the subject position”). 8 The same view was adopted in Bouchard (1984), Marantz (1984), Grimshaw (1990), and Pesetsky (1995), but Reinhart and Siloni (2004) have convincingly argued against analyzing reflexive SE-verbs as unaccusatives and have proposed instead that they behave as unergatives.

subsection.heading: 2.1.3.1 Reflexive SE-verbs are not transitives
subsection.p: The empirical evidence reviewed in this subsection was invoked by Burzio (1981) and subsequently by most GB theorists in favor of the unaccusative analysis. On closer scrutiny, however, these are not arguments in favor of the putative unaccusative behavior of reflexive verbs. What the facts really show is that reflexive SE-verbs do not pattern with transitives, which means that reflexive SE is not an object clitic.

Clear evidence against the pronominal status of SE is provided by French causatives. Pronominal clitics cannot attach to a verb embedded under causative faire, whereas this position is accessible to SE:

(4)
a. *La crainte du scandale l’a fait la tuer.
the fear of scandal him-has made her kill.
‘The fear of scandal made him kill her.’
b. La crainte du scandale l’a fait se tuer.
the fear of scandal him-has made SE kill.
‘The fear of scandal made him kill himself.’

Consider next the paradigm in (5a–f). According to a clear empirical generalization, the underlying subject of an infinitival clause embedded under a causative faire must be preceded by the preposition à in case a direct object is present, but lacks à with intransitive verbs (see (5a–c)). The example in (5d) shows that pronominal clitics behave on a par with object DPs (see (5c)), whereas the grammaticality of (5e), without à, and the ungrammaticality of (5f), where à is present, indicate that SE does not function as a direct object:

(5)
a. Jean a fait manger Marie.
John has made eat Mary
‘John let Mary eat.’
b. *Jean a fait manger à Marie.
c Jean a fait manger la soupe à Marie.
John has made eat the soup to Mary
‘John let Mary eat the soup.’
d. Jean li’a fait manger ei à Marie.
John it-has made eat to Mary
‘John let it eat to Mary.’
e. La crainte du scandale a fait se tuer la mère du juge.
The fear of scandal has made SE kill the mother of the judge.
‘The fear of scandal made the mother of the judge kill herself.’
f. *La crainte du scandale a fait se tuer à la mère du juge.
The fear of scandal has made SE kill to-the mother of the judge.

The two tests just discussed for French cannot be used in other Romance languages such as Romanian or Italian: Romanian does not have counterparts of faire-causatives, and in Italian, fare-causatives block the cliticization of SE on the embedded infinitival (Burzio 1986):

(6)
a. *Questo farà [VP pentirsi Giovanni]
This will make John repentSI
b. *Maria ha fatto [VP accusarsi Piero]
Mary has made accuseSE Peter
‘Mary has made Peter accuse himself.’
Burzio (1986: 410) attempts to correlate the contrast between Italian and French with the difference between free subject inversion and il-impersonals, but the issue remains open. 9

subsection.heading: 2.1.3.2 Reflexive SE-verbs are not unaccusatives
subsection.p: Burzio's (1986) data reviewed above show that SE-reflexives do not behave as transitive verbs accompanied by object clitics. Although the data are compatible with both the unergative and the unaccusative analysis, Burzio favored the unaccusative hypothesis: reflexive SE would be an unaccusative marker that suspends the subject theta-role: SE-affixation to a transitive verb, e.g., accuse, would be a morphological process that gives rise to a corresponding verb, ‘self-accuse’, which is an unaccusative verb (1986: 415). Reinhart and Siloni (2004) argued conclusively against the unaccusative analysis of SE-reflexives. Under their view, SE-reflexives are unergatives.

Arguing in favor of the unaccusative analysis of reflexives, Burzio (1986) observed that the object of transitives and the subject of unaccusatives (cf. arrivare as well as SE-marked unaccusatives) can be relativized via small-clause relativization, in contrast with the subject of unergatives and transitives:

(7)
a. uno studente [scPROi invitato ti alla festa]
a student (who was) invited to the party
b. uno studente [PROi arrivato ti ieri sera]
a student (who had) arrived yesterday evening
c. L’auto capovoltasi nell’incidente era la Ferrari.
The car (which had) rolled over in the accident was the Ferrari.
d. Un pilota accortosi dell’incidente diede l’allarme.
A driver (who had) become aware of the accident gave the warning.

(8)
a. *uno studente [PRO telefonato ieri sera]
a student (who had) telephoned yesterday evening
b. *Un individuo accusatolo di aver assassinato il presidente fu creduto pazzo.
A guy (who had) accused him of having assassinated the president was thought (to be) crazy.
c. *un individuo accusato se stesso di aver assassinato il presidente
a guy (who had) accused himself of having assassinated the president
SE-reflexives behave on a par with unaccusatives:
(9) Un individuo accusatosi di aver assassinato il presidente fu creduto pazzo. A man (who had) accused himself of having assassinated the president was believed crazy.
Reinhart and Siloni observed, however, that not all reflexives are allowed to occur in Italian reduced relatives:

(10)
*L’uomo lavatosi ieri è mio nonno.
The man washed-SE yesterday is my grandfather.
Burzio himself brought up empirical evidence going against his own proposal; in particular, SE-reciprocals cannot appear in reduced relatives:
(11) ?Due amici incontratisi allo stadio non si vedevano d’anni.
A second argument in favor of the unaccusativity of SE-reflexives is based on auxiliary selection: they select the auxiliary be, in contrast with both transitives and unergatives, which select have:

(12)
a. Jean s’est puni.
John SE-has punished
b. Jean s’est lavé le visage.
John SE-has washed his face
c. Il s’est mangé 300 kg de viande.
there SE-has eaten 300 kg of meat
Reinhart and Siloni observe that auxiliary selection is not a decisive argument in favor of unaccusativity, since be is selected by transitive verbs taking a dative SE: 10

(13)
Marie s’est envoyé une carte du Maroc.
Mary SE-has sent a postcard from Morocco

Further evidence against the unaccusativity of SE-reflexives is related to the distribution of en. Thus, although reflexives (marginally) allow their subject DP to occupy the postverbal position (presumably the direct object position) in French il-impersonals, en-extraction is blocked by SE-reflexives, in contradistinction to SE-unaccusatives and SE-passives, which behave on a par with unmarked unaccusatives and copula passives:

(14)
a. Il s’en est cassé beaucoup dans ce lave-vaisselle. (unaccusative)
there SE of them has broken many in this dish-washer
b. Il s’en est lavé beaucoup dans ces douches publiques récemment. (OK passive; *refl.)
there SE of them has washed many in these public showers recently
c. ?*Se ne sono incontratisi due.
SE of them have met two. (Burzio 1986: 424)

Note that quite independent of the distribution of en, the context of il-impersonals does not constitute clear evidence in favor of the unaccusative analysis of SE-reflexives. As shown in (15a), il-impersonals are productive and perfectly grammatical with unaccusatives (be they marked with SE or unmarked) and with periphrastic as well as SE-marked passives (Burzio 1981, 1986; Pollock 1981, 1983), but examples of the type in (15b), built with SE-reflexives, are quite hard to find:

(15)
a. Il s’est mangé 20 kg de viande en deux jours. (passive)
it SE ate 20 kg of meat in two days
b. ?Il s’est dénoncé trois mille hommes ce mois-ci. (reflexive)
it SE denounced 3,000 people this month (Kayne 1975: 381)

subsection.heading: 2.1.3.3 Reflexive SE and the Agent theta-role
subsection.p: Under later implementations of the unaccusative analysis of reflexives, reflexive SE was assumed to absorb the external theta-role (see Marantz 1984; Kayne 1988; Guéron 1991; Pesetsky 1995; Sportiche 1998), on a par with passive SE. In section 3 below, we will show that the hypothesis that accusative SE absorbs the external theta-role is problematic for passive SE. Those problems transfer to reflexive SE.

subsection.heading: 2.1.3.4 Reflexive SE-verbs are unergatives
subsection.p: We have so far reviewed the evidence against two possible analyses of SE-reflexives: they are neither transitives nor unaccusatives. Reinhart and Siloni (2004) propose instead that SE-reflexives are unergatives, obtained from their transitive alternates by an operation that identifies the two arguments of a two-place relation. In certain languages, e.g., Hebrew, this identification takes place in the lexicon, in which case it amounts to a lexical reduction operation that reduces a two-place relation to a property (Chierchia 1989; Reinhart 1997). In Romance languages, on the other hand, reflexivization relies on an identification operation that takes place at LF. Whereas lexical reduction is restricted to apply to co-arguments, LF-identification may apply to arguments of two distinct predicates, as in ECM constructions:

(16)
Jean se considère [e intelligent].
John SE considers intelligent
‘John considers himself (to be) intelligent.’
Hebrew counterparts of this kind of example are ungrammatical, because Hebrew reflexivization can only resort to lexical reduction.

subsection.heading: 2.1.4 Unifying characterizations of accusative SE
subsection.p: Beyond important differences, non-reflexive accusative SE-verbs (inherent SE-verbs, inchoatives, middles, and passives) can all be argued to be unaccusatives 11 insofar as the external role is suspended (i.e., not realized in the syntax), and the internal role is realized as a subject (in particular, it is assigned nominative Case). 12

In the preceding section we have concluded, following Reinhart and Siloni (2004), that the unaccusative analysis of SE-reflexives should be discarded. And yet a unifying analysis of reflexive and non-reflexive accusative SE-verbs is desirable, due to very clear cross-linguistic generalizations: (i) Romance languages all have both reflexive and non-reflexive accusative SE; and (ii) many languages other than Romance have a non-active voice that is used both for reflexives and for inchoatives and middle-passives.

subsection.heading: 2.1.4.1 Lexical accounts
subsection.p: It is widely agreed that accusative SE does not function as an object clitic, but rather as a morphological marker that affects argument structure at the level of the lexicon. This general characterization is compatible with quite different lexical rules, e.g., Inchoativization, Reflexivization, or Middle Formation (Grimshaw 1982). According to Reinhart and Siloni (2004), the SE-morphology appears when some derivational operation has taken place, be it reduction, saturation, or reflexivization (identification). 13

One may wonder why operations as distinct as lexical reduction (which itself comes in two flavors: reduction of the external or of the internal role, corresponding respectively to unaccusatives and reflexives), LF-identification, or saturation (postulated in the analysis of passives and middles by Chierchia 1989 and Reinhart 1997) should be marked by one and the same morphological marker, SE.

Similar questions arise for other lexicalist analyses, in particular for Wehrli's (1986) view that the unifying characteristic of SE is that it absorbs an argument. According to this author, the various instantiations of SE are obtained by combining two parameters: (i) which argument is absorbed; and (ii) whether the absorption operation is lexicalized or not:

(17)
a. Inherent SE: absorption of the internal argument; lexicalized
b. Unaccusative SE: absorption of the external argument; lexicalized
c. Reflexive SE: absorption of the internal argument; non-lexicalized
d. Middle SE: absorption of the external argument; non-lexicalized
But why should one and the same element absorb either one of the two arguments, despite the fact that it is uniformly marked with accusative Case?

subsection.heading: 2.1.4.2 SE as an anaphor
subsection.p: Dobrovie-Sorin (1994b, 1998) argues that the GB notion of anaphor (defined as an element that is subject to Principle A of Binding Theory) provides a unified characterization of the various types of accusative SE. According to a restricted theory of binding, only elements that occupy A-positions are subject to binding conditions. Under such a theory, binding conditions do not apply to clitics, but only to their traces. In particular, the anaphoric feature of SE, which is registered in the lexicon, is transferred to a designated A-position. A sentence containing SE will thus of necessity rely on the indexing configuration given in (18), where NPi and ei occupy respectively the subject and the object positions. The ‘complete’ version of the representation in (18) is (18′):
(18) NPi ei
(18′) NPi SEi ei

The absence of SE in (18) is only meant to indicate that the S-structure position of SE is irrelevant for Binding Theory, although, of course, the position of SE is crucial for phenomena having to do with cliticization; e.g., clitic climbing in faire-causatives or restructuring environments, etc.

The assignment of indices in (18–18′) characterizes reflexive as well as unaccusative uses of SE, which differ regarding thematic structure, as shown in (19a–b), or the fully developed representations in (19′a–b):

(19)
a. (NPi) (ei)
b. (NPi ei)

(19′)
a. (NPi) (SEi ei)
b. (NPi SEi ei)

The representation in (19b) differs from that in (19a) insofar as the two co-indexed argument positions belong to the same theta-chain. The two-chain configuration given in (19a) underlies SE-reflexives, which are characterized by an identification relation between the internal and the external arguments, 14 whereas the representation in (19b) underlies the non-reflexive uses of accusative SE-verbs (inherent, inchoative, middle, and passive SE-verbs), 15 which qualify as unaccusatives. 16

In sum, the possibility of similar and yet distinct syntactic configurations is the result of the modularity of GB theory. The common property of SE-constructions pertains to binding theory (SE is lexically marked as an anaphor, and as such it forces the binding/co-indexation relation that characterizes both (19a) and (19b)), 17 whereas their dissimilarities pertain to theta-theory: one and the same binding relation may form one or two theta-chains, depending on the lexical properties of the predicates.

Postma (1995a) shares with Dobrovie-Sorin (1994b, 1998) the hypothesis that the unifying property of all uses of accusative SE is its being an anaphor, but proposes a different analysis. Postma assumes that the Agent role is projected in the syntax and that the various readings of SE arise as a consequence of the way in which the theta-chain corresponding to the Agent role is identified with the Theme-chain (for further details of Postma's proposal see section 3.5. below). In section 3 it will be argued that the Agent is not projected in the syntax of SE-verbs (other than reflexives), and in section 5 it will be shown that agentive or non-agentive interpretations depend on the syntactic position in which the internal argument is realized.

subsection.heading: 2.2 Dative SE 18
subsection.p: In most Romance languages, dative SE is homophonous with accusative SE (cf. French, Italian, Spanish, Portuguese):

(20)
a. Marie se fait des robes. French
Mary SE makes dresses
‘Mary makes dresses for herself.’
b. Jean s’est envoyé des cartes postales.
John SE HAS sent postcards
In Romanian, reflexive clitics show an overt case distinction: se for accusatives and îşi for datives. The Romanian counterparts of the French examples in (20) are given in (21):

(21)
a. Maria îşi face rochii.
Mary SEDat makes dresses
b. Ion şi-a trimis cǎr tcedil i poştale. (şi is the phonologically weak form of îşi)
John SEDat-has sent postcards

Kayne (1975) observed that in French, dative SE cannot be bound by a derived subject, i.e., a subject that is the head of an NP-chain resulting from NP-movement (cf. passives and subject-raising configurations). Rizzi (1986b) showed that the generalization also holds in Italian ((22) for − passives, (23–24) for − subject raising):

(22)
a. *Giannii sii è stato affidato ei.
John SI HAS been entrusted
‘John to-himself was entrusted.’
b. *I nostri amicii sii sono stati presentati ei.
our friends SI HAVE been introduced
‘Our friends to-each-other were introduced.’

(23)
a. *Giannii sii sembra [ei non fare il suo dovere].
John SI seems not (to) do his duty
‘John to-himself seems not to do his duty.’
b. *Le due candidatii sii risultavano [ei poter vincere].
the two candidates SI appeared (to) be able (to) win
‘The two candidates to-each-other appeared to be able to win.’

(24)
a. *Giannii sii sembra [ei intelligente].
John SI seems intelligent
‘John to-himself seems intelligent.’
b. *Loroi sii risultano [ei in regola con le tasse].
(they) SI appear in good order with taxes
‘They to-each-other appear in good order with the taxes.’
Non-clitic anaphors such as se stesso or l’uno l’altro are not subject to this constraint:

(25)
a. Giannii è stato affidato a se stessii .
John HAS been entrusted to himself
b. I nostri amicii sono stati presentati l’uno all’altroi.
our friends HAVE been introduced to each other

The restriction observed with passives and raising verbs also holds in adjectival constructions, as shown in the (b) examples below. The (a) examples, which contain the corresponding non-clitic anaphors, are grammatical:

(26)
a. Giannii è [ei affezionato a se stessoi].
John is affectionate to himself
b. *Giannii sii è [ei affezionato].
John SI is affectionate

(27)
a. Loroi sono simili [ei l’uno all’altro].
they are similar to each other
b. *Loroi sii sono [ei simili].
they SI are similar

(28)
a. Loroi sono [ei odiosi I’uno all’altroi].
they are hateful to each other
b. *Loroi sii sono [ei odiosi].
they SI are hateful

The observed parallelism between A-chain configurations (passives and subject raising) and adjectival constructions is expected under the GB analysis of adjectives, going back to Couquaux (1979, 1981): the copula verb be is assumed to take a small-clause complement headed by the adjective; the subject position of be, which is empty at D-structure (because be assigns no theta-role) is targeted by the NP-movement of the subject of the small clause.

Verbs that are semantically close to the adjectives in (26–28) do not trigger ungrammaticality, presumably because in this case the subject is not the head of an A-chain but instead is base-generated in its S-structure position:

(29)
a. Loroi sii assomigliano ei.
(they) SI resemble
‘They resemble each other.’
b. Loroi sii fanno ei pena/tenerezza/simpatia.
(they) SI make pain/tenderness/liking
‘They make pain/tenderness/liking to-each-other.’

Kayne's (1975) account of the phenomenon relied on an extrinsic ordering of the rules of passivization and reflexive cliticization: the former applies before the latter, and the observed ungrammaticality obtains because reflexivization requires SE to be co-indexed with a subject, a requirement that cannot be satisfied: the prior application of passivization has suspended the external theta-role, and the object-to-subject NP-movement has not yet applied.

Burzio's (1986: 397–399) explanation builds on the same idea, but differs in the technical implementation. The ungrammaticality of dative SE with derived subjects would be due to the fact that the co-indexation relation between SE and a subject in Spec, IP, which defines SE, cannot be satisfied at D-structure in the relevant configurations: within the model of grammar assumed by Burzio, passives and raising verbs are generated with an empty Spec, IP position.

Rizzi (1986) rejected Burzio's account on the grounds that it stipulates an idiosyncratic property of SE, that of requiring a co-indexation with a subject at all levels of representation (in particular at D-structure), and he proposed instead an explanation relying on a Chain Condition: the chain in (30), representing a dative SE bound by a subject heading an A-chain, is ill-formed because the NP-trace (resulting from the NP-movement of the subject) is unduly locally bound by SE:
(30) *NPi SEi tNPi

This solution raises both empirical and theoretical problems. Note first that configurations of the type in (30) are grammatical in English, where the intervening binder is a strong dative reflexive pronoun:

(31)
a. Maryi seems [to herselfi] ti to have done her duty.
b. Johni appeared [to himselfi] ti to be capable of doing the job.

Within Rizzi's proposal one could account for the grammaticality of (31) by assuming that the reflexive pronoun, because it is embedded inside a PP, does not C-command the NP-trace, and thus does not count as a disturbing intervening binder. Pesetsky (1995: 105) observes that C-command must be postulated in exactly the same configuration in order to account for Principle C violations:
(32) *Maryj seems [to himi] tj to like Johni.
A comparable problem is raised by Romanian, a language in which the dative clitic îşi can be bound by derived subjects: 19

(33)
a. Ion şi Maria şi-au fost prezenta tcedil i anul trecut.
John and Mary SEdat-have been presented year-the last
‘John and Mary were presented to each other last year.’
b. Ion îşi e recunoscǎtor numai lui.
John SEdat is grateful only to him(self)
c. Ion şi Maria şi-au devenit pur şi simplu insuportabili.
John and Mary SEdat-have become purely and simply unbearable (to each other)
‘John and Mary have become purely and simply unbearable to each other.’

Romanian clearly differs from French and Italian insofar as dative and accusative reflexive clitics are overtly distinguished by morphological Case: îşi and se respectively. Given Rizzi's account, one would have to say that morphological Case-marking blocks C-command. This proposal faces the problem noted above for English, regarding Principle C violations:

(34)
*Maria îij para a-lj place pe Ionj. 20
Romanian
Maryi to-himj seems to [ei] himj like Johnj.

It should be noted that although Rizzi's (1986) Chain Condition has the flavor of Rizzi's (1990b) Relativized Minimality Constraint, Rizzi (1990b) does not attempt to restate it. The reason might be that the Chain Condition cannot be restated in terms of relativized minimality: SE is an A′-antecedent, and as such it should not disturb the relation between an NP-trace and its antecedent, because the latter sits in an A-position.

Following a suggestion by Kayne, Pesetsky (1995: 103–105) proposes an explanation based on a Marantz–Kayne type of analysis for SE (see section 3.6): SE would necessarily be an external argument, regardless of whether it gives rise to reflexive, passive, or middle interpretations, and regardless of its Case: nominative, accusative, and dative SEs all need to absorb the external theta-role. The ungrammaticality shown in (22–24) and (26b), (27b), and (28b) would then be due to the fact that there is no external theta-role available for absorption by SE, since passives, raising verbs, and be do not assign an external theta-role. This solution does not explain why a dative SE that bears morphological dative Case, as in Romanian, does not need to absorb the external theta-role.

The problems faced by Rizzi (1986) and later proposals do not arise within Burzio's account, the only defect of which seems to be that it stipulates that the co-indexation relation required by SE (by virtue of its being an anaphor) should hold at all levels of representation, in particular at D-structure. This proposal is also confronted by a theory-internal problem, due to the evolution of the generative model: in the various versions of Minimalism, the D-structure level of representation is eliminated. It seems possible to solve this problem, while at the same time giving a conceptual justification to Burzio's proposal, by slightly modifying it: the co-indexing requirement imposed by SE would hold in the lexicon rather than at D-structure. The reason why it should hold in this component of the grammar would simply be its lexical nature: on a par with accusative SE, dative SE would be a lexical affix (rather than a pronominal clitic; see section 2.1.3), which as such should satisfy its anaphoric feature in the lexicon itself. This requirement cannot be satisfied if we assume that passives, adjectives, and raising verbs do not have external arguments in the lexicon. Because strong pronominal anaphors such as l’uno l’altro or se stessi are pronominal anaphors rather than lexical affixes, they do not function as anaphors in the lexicon, but only in the syntax: hence, they can be bound by derived subjects, i.e., elements that fill the (Spec, IP) position at S-structure. Similarly, we may explain the Romanian data by assuming that reflexives that are overtly marked for dative Case function as pronominal clitics rather than lexical affixes, and therefore the binding conditions are to be satisfied in the syntax rather than in the lexicon.

subsection.heading: 2.3 Nominative SE
subsection.p: Only certain pro-drop Romance languages – in particular Italian, Spanish, and Portuguese – have a nominative/subject SE:

(35)
a. Non sii ei è mai contenti. Italian
not SI is ever satisfied
‘One is never satisfied.’
b. Spesso sii ei è traditi dai falsi amici.
frequently SI is betrayed by false friends
‘One is frequently betrayed by false friends.’ (SI+passive)
c. In questa università sii ei studia le materie letterarie.
in this university SI teaches the humanities
d. (Le materie letterarie) le sii ei studia in questa università.
(the humanities) them SI teaches in this university
‘(The humanities) one teaches them in this university.’

(35a–b) cannot involve an accusative SE because neither (the copula verb be +) adjectives nor passives can assign accusative Case. In (35c), the verb does not agree with le materie letterarie; therefore this DP cannot be a postverbal subject, but must instead be analyzed as a direct object; since direct objects take accusative Case, SE itself cannot be accusative. In (35d), accusative Case is assigned to the object clitic le, and is thus unavailable for SE itself. The examples in (35a–d) are instead compatible with analyzing SE as an arbitrary subject clitic (marked with abstract nominative Case) comparable to arbitrary on ‘one’ in French.

Romance scholars have frequently attempted to unify nominative and accusative SE (see, among others, Castelfranchi and Parisi 1976; Manzini 1986b; Guéron 1991; Kayne (class lectures in the 1980s and 1990s)). According to Manzini (1986b), what brings together all the occurrences of si is the fact that si is co-indexed with the subject NP. This suggested unification is, however, problematic, since the co-indexation convention notates here two distinct types of dependency relations. It is by virtue of being a subject clitic that nominative si is co-indexed with the subject position. Accusative si, on the other hand, is co-indexed with the subject not because it is a clitic, but rather because it is an anaphor. Since it notates two distinct types of dependency relations (a subject clitic chain and an A-chain, respectively), the co-indexation itself cannot be viewed as a common property of the two sis, which means that Manzini's unification attempt fails. According to Kayne (1986), the unifying property of all uses of SE is the fact that it absorbs the external role. As we will demonstrate in section 3 below, the notion of ‘absorption’ was used to refer to two irreconcilable operations:

li.p: The external theta-role may be ‘absorbed’ but nevertheless projected in the canonical syntactic position of subjects. This kind of absorption characterizes nominative clitics (and agreement morphemes in pro-drop languages), in particular nominative SE, but crucially not passivizing morphemes.

The external theta-role may be ‘suspended’, i.e., not projected in the subject position; it remains present in argument-structure and may surface as an adjunct by-phrase. The suspension of the external role characterizes passivizing morphemes in general, and middle-passive SE in particular, but cannot be correct for nominative SE.

subsection.p: Note that a unified approach to accusative and nominative SEs would predict that these two types of SE necessarily co-occur cross-linguistically, but this prediction is incorrect. It is indeed clear that French does not have nominative SE. Moreover, Dobrovie-Sorin (1986, 1987, 1994b, 1998) has established that although it is a pro-drop language, Romanian lacks nominative SE. 21 Thus, the Romanian counterparts of the Italian examples in (35) are all ungrammatical:

(36)
a. *Nu se este niciodatǎ mul tcedil umit. Romanian
not SE is never satisfied
‘One is never satisfied.’
b. *Adesea se este trǎdat de prieteni falşi.
frequently SE is betrayed by false friends
‘One is frequently betrayed by false friends.’
c. *În aceastǎ universitate se predǎ ştiin tcedil ele umane.
in this university SE teaches the humanities
d. *(Stiin tcedil ele umane) le se predǎ în aceastǎ universitate.
(the humanities) them SE teaches in this university

The contrast between Spanish and Romanian illustrated in (37–38) constitutes further evidence in favor of the lack of nominative SE in Romanian. Since Spanish SE may be nominative, it may co-occur with a prepositional accusative. Since Romanian SE is of necessity accusative, it blocks the occurrence of a prepositional accusative:

(37)
En esta escuela se castiga a los alumnos. Spanish
in this school SE punishes a the students
‘In this school they punish the students.’

(38)
*În şcoala asta se pedepseşte pe elevi. Romanian
in this school SE punishes PE students
‘In this school they punish the students.’

Given that all Romance languages have accusative SE, but only some of them have nominative SE, we may assume, in line with Belletti (1982), Burzio (1981, 1986), Zribi-Hertz (1982), Hyams (1986), Zubizarreta (1987), and Dobrovie-Sorin (1986, 1994b, 1998), that these two SEs are homophonous, but clearly distinct linguistic entities as different from each other as man ‘one’ and sich in German or on ‘one’ and se in French.

Although some empirical intricacies related to the distribution of SE in Italian infinitivals made Burzio (1982, 1986) wrongly believe that middle-passive SE is a particular type of nominative SE (see sections 3.4 and 4 below), Burzio proposed clearly different analyses for accusative and nominative SE, which can still be maintained modulo technical restatements due to the evolution of the GB model itself. Burzio's (1986) characterization of the distinction is stated in terms of the level at which SE is inserted: (the core cases of) accusative SEs are analyzed as lexical affixes marking unaccusativity, which absorb/suspend the external theta-role at the level of the lexicon and are base-generated directly in their S-structure position (this is true for simple predicates; in complex predicates, e.g., causatives and restructuring environments, one must allow for clitic climbing). Nominative SE, on the other hand, behaves as a pronominal clitic: it is subject to clitic movement, and functions as an argument, being assigned a theta-role via a clitic chain.

The homonymical treatment of nominative and accusative SEs is confronted with some potential problems: auxiliary selection, relative order with respect to object clitics, and negation seem to treat the two SEs alike. Although these problems have not yet received a satisfactory solution, they do not seem to affect the view that nominative SE and accusative middle-passive SE should be treated as homonyms rather than as instantiations of the same element. This does not mean that the homonymy itself is completely accidental. It is, indeed, known that nominative SE developed via a diachronic reanalysis from accusative SE. According to Naro (1976), constructions of the type SE V NP, involving passive SE, came to be reanalyzed as an S-V-O sequence, with SE taken as a subject pronoun. This reanalysis took place in Italian, Spanish, and Portuguese, but not in French or Romanian. In sum, the existence vs. the absence of nominative SE is a parameter according to which Romance languages that have middle-passive SE vary: Italian, Spanish, and Portuguese have both nominative and accusative SE, whereas Romanian and French have only accusative SE. This variation is expected under the homonymical analysis of nominative and accusative SE, since the existence of particular pairs of homonyms is language-specific.

subsection.heading: 2.4 When SE combines with unergatives
subsection.p: Italian (and Spanish or Portuguese) constructions of the type si dorme ‘SE sleeps’, in which SE combines with unergatives, rely on nominative SE, but their Romanian counterparts cannot be assigned this analysis, because Romanian does not have nominative SE (see section 2.3 above):

(39)
si canta/si dorme . . . /si mangia Italian
SE sings/SE sleeps/ . . . SE eats
‘one sings/one sleeps/ . . . one eats’

(40)
se cîntǎ/se doarme/se munceşte/se mǎnîncǎ Romanian
SE sings/SE sleeps/SE works/SE eats
According to Dobrovie-Sorin (1986, 1994b), examples such as (40) rely on a passivizing accusative SE, comparable to impersonal middle sich in German: 22

(41)
Es lebt sich angenehm hier. German
it lives SICH in a pleasant way here
‘Life is pleasant here.’

subsection.heading: 2.4.1 The passivization of unergatives
subsection.p: The passive phenomenon is currently described as involving the suspension of the external theta-role and of accusative Case; correlatively, the internal argument is NP-moved from the object to the subject position (see chapter 2). Because unergatives are currently viewed as being unable to subcategorize a direct object, Marantz (1984), Baker (1988a), and Sobin (1985), among many others, were led to modify and parameterize the analysis of passivization. The core property of passives was relaxed, merely requiring the suspension of the external role (the precise technical stipulation differs from one author to the other, and is of no interest here). This analysis of impersonal passives, described as the spontaneous demotion of the Agent by Perlmutter (1978), has become general across grammatical models. This kind of analysis stipulates two distinct rules of passivization: one for transitives and another one for unergatives. Moreover, no real understanding of the cross-linguistic variation shown by the passivization of unergatives was achieved: the impossibility of passivizing unergatives in certain languages is assumed to be due to the parameterization of either passive morphemes or unergatives, but no independent evidence can be adduced in favor of either one of these parameters.

Dobrovie-Sorin (1986, 1994b, 1998) proposed a different line of inquiry, based on the hypothesis that the passivization of unergatives relies on exactly the same rule as the passivization of transitives. 23 Under this view, the structure underlying the example in (42c), where se combines with an unergative, is exactly the same as that underlying (42a) and (42b), constructed with a transitive. This analysis relies on the hypothesis that unergatives may project a null cognate object: 24

(42)
a. Si-au mîncat proi ei ieri.
SEi-HAVE-3rd plur eaten proi ei yesterday
‘They were eaten yesterday.’
b. Si-a mîncat proi ei bine ieri.
SEi-HAS-3rd sing eaten proi ei well here
it was eaten well yesterday
‘We/they ate well yesterday.’
c. Sei doarme proi ei bine aici.
SEi sleeps-3rd sing proi ei well here
it is slept well here
‘One sleeps well here.’

According to Dobrovie-Sorin's analysis, these examples rely on chains of the form (pro, e), made up of a null subject (its exact position is not directly relevant here: one may assume either (Spec, VP) or (Spec, IP)) and of an empty category that occupies the direct object position; this chain is marked with the Theme role, assigned in the object position. 25 The only difference between (42a, b, and c) concerns the interpretation of this chain (referential, protoypical, and cognate objects respectively), which depends on the selectional properties of the verb.

This analysis of middle-passive unergatives seems to be facilitated by Hale and Keyser's (1993a) hypothesis that unergatives are universally transitive in their lexical relational structure; that is, they are to be represented as being derived by the incorporation of cognate objects into light verbs. Note, however, that this view on the lexical representation of unergatives does not oblige us, and perhaps does not even authorize us, to assume that the traces of the incorporated cognate objects are projected in the syntax. According to Dobrovie-Sorin (1986, 1994b, 1998), the presence of null cognate objects in the syntactic representation of passive unergatives is not induced by the lexical properties of unergatives (unergatives merely allow the presence of a direct object), but rather by the properties of passive configurations, and in particular by the properties of middle-passive SE. Note that this proposal does not entail that null prototypical and cognate objects are projected in the S-structure representation of active unergatives or intransitively used transitives.

subsection.heading: 2.4.2 Does SE combine with unaccusatives?
subsection.p: According to a well-known generalization, unaccusative verbs cannot passivize. 26 Given this generalization, we expect examples such as (43) to be ungrammatical in Italian:

(43)
a. *Ritengo non essersi arrivati in sufficiente anticipo.
(I) believe not to HAVE-SE arrived sufficiently ahead of time
b. *Non essendosi morti in giovane età
not HAVING-SE died young
c. *Sembra essersi arrivati troppo tardi.
(it) seems to HAVE-SI arrived too late

These examples are ungrammatical because SE can be neither nominative (because nominative SE is ruled out in Italian non-finite clauses; see section 4 below) nor a passivizing accusative SE (because unaccusatives cannot passivize).
Quite surprisingly, however, the Romanian examples in (44) are grammatical:

(44)
a. Ieri s-a ajuns la timp.
yesterday SE-has arrived in time
‘Yesterday people arrived on time.’
b. La noi, se moare des din cauza cancerului şi a bolilor cardiace.
here/in our country SE dies frequently because of cancer and of cardiac diseases
‘Here/in our country people die frequently from cancer and from cardiac diseases.’
c. Nu se moare din atîta.
not SE dies of that much
‘One does not die from so little.’
d. In salǎ se amu tcedil este la apari tcedil ia examinatorului.
in the classroom SE goes quiet when the examiner appears
‘Everyone goes quiet when the examiner shows up in the classroom.’
e. Se întîrzie zilnic.
SE arrives late every day
‘People arrive/are late every day.’
f. Dupǎ medicamentele astea, sigur se va învia!
after (having taken) medicines-the these, for sure SE will resurrect
‘People will surely be restored to life after having taken these drugs.’
g. La temperatura de −20 grade, se degerǎ.
at the temperature of −20 degrees, SE freezes

Given this type of data, one might be led to conclude, contra Dobrovie-Sorin, that Romanian does have a nominative SE. The solution suggested by Dobrovie-Sorin (1987, 1994b) herself is that in Romanian, the distinction between unergatives and unaccusatives is not grammatically encoded. Indeed, most of the current tests of unaccusativity cannot be used in Romanian: this language does not use be as a perfect auxiliary (all verbs are built with have), and it has no counterpart of the French clitic en (Italian ne).

One may, however, wonder whether there is any limitation on the use of passive SE with verbs that are semantically close to unaccusatives. And indeed, there exist at least two types of impossibilities (Panǎ-Dindelegan, p.c.). On the one hand, passive SE cannot apply to inherent reflexives. Thus, verbs such as a se aglomera, a se atrofia, a se bifurca, a se bronza, a se caria, a se cicatriza, a se înnora, a se învechi, a se îneca ‘to get crowded, to atrophy, to bifurcate, to get tanned, to get a cavity, to scar, to get cloudy, to get old, to drown’ cannot be used with an impersonal passive SE. Given that inherent reflexives are unaccusatives, they behave exactly as predicted by the hypothesis that unaccusatives cannot passivize.

The second limitation concerns the type of subject selected by the verb: a one-argument verb can be used with an impersonal passive SE only if it is construed as involving a human argument. Thus, examples such as Vasul acosteazǎ ‘The ship is coming ashore’, Mi- a amor tcedil it piciorul ‘My leg went numb’, Soarele apune ‘The sun is going down’, Luna asfin tcedil eşte ‘The moon is going down’, Pomii au înfrunzit/înmugurit/înflorit ‘The trees grew leaves/budded/flowered’, Veniturile cresc/descresc ‘The income increases/decreases’ cannot give rise to impersonal forms. Some of these verbs may combine with impersonal SE, as shown in (45). But crucially, the implicit suspended argument can only be interpreted as human:

(45)
a. Dupǎ vîrsta de 60 de ani, se apune încet-încet!
after the age of 60, SE goes down slowly-slowly
‘People slowly fade after reaching the age of 60!’
b. S-a acostat departe de aici.
SE-has come ashore far from here
‘The landing was far from here.’
c. S-a amor tcedil it.
SE-has come numb
‘People got numb.’
d. Se creşte fǎrǎ griji.
SE grows up without worries
‘One grows up carefree.’

Although the constraint regarding the human feature of the implicit suspended argument of SE-passives is not well understood (see Mendikoetxea 1999), its existence supports the hypothesis that SE-passivization cannot apply to genuine unaccusatives: the human feature of the external argument makes it easier for a given verb to be construed as unergative, thus allowing for passivization.

subsection.heading: 2.4.3 Cross-linguistic variation: the passivization of unergatives and impersonal constructions
subsection.p: French clearly differs from Romanian in not allowing passive SE to combine with unergatives: 27

(46)
a. *Il se procédera à une enquête. French
IL SE will proceed to an inquiry
‘An inquiry will be started.’
b. *Il s’aboutira à un compromis acceptable.
IL SE will arrive at/reach an acceptable compromise
‘An acceptable compromise will be reached.’
c. *Il s’est tiré sur les manifestants.
IL SE-HAS shot at the demonstrators
‘The demonstrators were shot at.’
d. *Il se lui a été demandé/suggéré de partir.
IL him/herDat SE-has asked/ordered/suggested to leave
‘He/she was asked/ordered/suggested to leave.’

Cinque (1988) explains the ungrammaticality of (46) by parameterizing the types of SE, and by assuming that the SE that is allowed to combine with unergatives (analyzed as an impersonal passivizing +arg nominative SE by Cinque) does not exist in French. This kind of account is not available for Dobrovie-Sorin (1998), who argues against the existence of a nominative +arg SE (see section 4.1 below) and assumes that unergatives may combine with an accusative middle-passive SE. Since such an element exists in French, we would expect examples such as (46) to be grammatical.
One may choose to parameterize unergatives, as proposed by Jaeggli (1986):
(47) In certain languages (see German), but not in others (see French), unergatives assign structural Case.
The first problem with (47) is that it parameterizes a property that is currently assumed to be universal, namely the possibility for unergatives to assign structural Case.

Note furthermore that the parameter in (47) cannot account for a very clear empirical generalization: languages that (do not) admit se Vunerg also (do not) admit se Vtrans with a null prototypical object. Thus, the contrast between the Romanian examples in (42) and the French examples in (46) is parallelled by the contrast in (48a–b), where the verb is transitive in both languages:

(48)
a. Sei mǎnîncǎ proi ei prea mult aici. Romanian
SEi eats proi ei too much here
‘One eats too much here.’
b. *Ili sej mange ej trop ici. French
iti SEj eats ej too much here

Another problem raised by the parameterization of unergatives is that it cannot account for the fact that in one and the same language, French for example, unergatives may be used with copula passives, although they cannot be used with middle-passive se. Note indeed that the examples in (46) become grammatical if instead of the middle-passive se we use the copula passive:

(49)
a. Il sera procédé à une enquête.
IL will be proceeded to an inquiry
‘An inquiry will be undertaken.’
b. Il sera abouti à un compromis acceptable.
IL will be arrived at a compromise acceptable
‘An acceptable compromise will be reached.’
c. Il a été tiré sur les manifestants.
IL has been shot at the demonstrators
‘The demonstrators were shot at.’
d. Il lui a été demandé/ordonné/suggéré de partir.
IL himDat has been asked/ordered/suggested to leave
‘He was asked/ordered/suggested to leave.’ 28
If we tried to analyze the ungrammaticality of (46) as being due to some property of French unergatives, we would incorrectly expect the examples in (49) to be equally ungrammatical.

We are led to conclude that the cross-linguistic variation regarding the possibility or the impossibility of passivizing unergatives cannot be due to parameters bearing on either passivizing morphemes or unergatives. A possible line of investigation is to relate the possibility of passivizing unergatives to the syntactic properties of il-impersonals, by taking into account the constraints that bear on copula passives and on SE passives, respectively. Thus, SE is legitimate only if a binding relation can be established, but this requirement cannot be satisfied in (48b): the trace of SE and the expletive subject are contra-indexed; if these two elements are co-indexed, il no longer counts as an expletive, but rather as a referential pronoun, which conflicts with the selectional properties of unergatives: they select cognate objects. In sum, a violation of Principle A arises in French il-impersonals whenever SE combines with unergatives. Romanian impersonals, on the other hand, rely on free subject inversion, the syntactic properties of which make it possible for Principle A to be satisfied: in (48a), the trace of SE is A-bound by the null subject pro. Turning finally to the French examples in (49), constructed with a copula passive, they do not contain any lexical anaphor, and consequently Principle A is irrelevant.

subsection.heading: 3 SE-verbs and the representation of Agentivity
3.1 Suspension of the external theta-role: suppression or absorption?
subsection.p: Descriptively speaking, passive configurations can be characterized as follows: the internal argument of the corresponding active verb surfaces as a subject (it is either realized in the canonical subject position or else is part of an expletive–argument chain), and this necessarily correlates with the fact that the Agent role is not realized in the subject position. In somewhat more theoretical terms, passive ‘morphemes’ (cf. the -en suffix or passive SE) can be assumed to suspend the Agent role and correlatively block the assignment of accusative Case. For this generalization, as well as for many other issues brought up below (the realization of external arguments, the relations between lexicon and syntax), see chapter 2.

One way of understanding the suspension of the external theta-role is to identify it with its suppression. It is indeed clear that in the case of inchoatives, middles, or adjectival passives, the Agent role manifests no ‘syntactic activity’ (see section 3.2 below), although middles (unlike inchoatives and adjectival passives) arguably involve some kind of implicit agentivity.

Verbal passives in general, and passive SE configurations in particular, differ from inchoatives, adjectival passives, and middles in exhibiting agentivity: tests such as Agent-oriented adverbs or control into purpose clauses have been recurrently invoked in favor of the hypothesis that in passive configurations, the Agent is not suppressed but, quite on the contrary, syntactically realized (see chapter 34).

What is, then, the syntactic position occupied by the Agent in passives? By the very definition of passives given above, a ‘suspended’ Agent is not projected onto the subject position. One possibility is to assume that the Agent of passives is realized as an overt or covert by-phrase (Chomsky 1965; Wasow 1977; Jaeggli 1986; Åfarli 1989; Schoorlemmer 1995). Other authors believe that implicit Agents are realized as pro or PRO (see chapter 34). Still other theorists propose that it is the passive morpheme itself that constitutes the syntactic realization of the Agent role (this assumption was made for passive SE by Belletti 1982 and for the past participle morpheme -en by Baker et al. 1989).

In what follows, we will first review the empirical evidence adduced in favor of the hypothesis that passive SE absorbs the external role (section 3.2). The various implementations of this widely assumed hypothesis 29 will then be discussed and rejected (sections 3.3–3.6). The concluding remarks (section 3.7) will establish an essentially negative result: in passive configurations, the Agent is not projected onto a subject(-like) position; nor can passive SE itself be assumed to function as an external argument; tests such as control into adjunct clauses or Agent-oriented adverbs do not prove the existence of a syntactically realized Agent (Williams 1985).

subsection.heading: 3.2 Control
subsection.p: Belletti (1982) proposed that the external theta-role is absorbed rather than merely suspended by passive SE. Belletti believed that this hypothesis could explain why, in contradistinction to analytic passives (be + past participle), passive SE is incompatible with a by-phrase (e.g., Ce poème s’est lu hier pendant la fête (*par Marie) ‘This poem SE HAS read yesterday during the party (*by Mary)’): because the Agent theta-role is realized as SE, it cannot surface as a by-phrase. Belletti's hypothesis was extended to analytic passives by Baker et al. (1989), who assume that the Agent role is absorbed by the passive morpheme -en. Under this view, the different distribution of by-phrases in passive SE configurations as opposed to analytic passives can no longer be explained.

Belletti (1982) assumed Agent-absorption by SE not only for passive but also for middle SE, which also implies some kind of agentivity (in clear contrast with, e.g., inchoative SE). This unifying hypothesis conflicts with a clear split between the two constructions: certain types of adjunct clauses can be controlled by the implicit Agent of (analytic or SE-marked) passives, but not by that of middles (the latter are identifiable by the property reading):

(50)
a. Les livres ont été vendus pour aider les pauvres. French
‘The books were sold in order to help the poor.’
b. *Les livres se vendent facilement pour aider les pauvres. 30
‘The books [SE] sell easily in order to help the poor.’

(51)
a. Questi appartamenti si vendono volutamente occupati. Italian
these apartments SI sell deliberately occupied
‘These apartments are deliberately sold occupied.’
b. Quell’uomo politico si può corrompere (facilmente) per dimostrare la propria influenza.
that politician SI can bribe (easily) to show one's influence
‘That politician can be bribed (easily) in order to show one's influence.’
c. Il museo del campo si può visitare facilmente anche nudi.
the camping museum SI can visit even naked
‘The camping museum can be visited even naked.’

(52)
a. Questi appartamenti hanno il vantaggio di vendersi (*volutamente) occupati.
these apartments have the advantage of to sell-SI (*deliberately) occupied
‘These apartments have the advantage of being sold (*deliberately) occupied.’
b. Quell’uomo politico ha il vantaggio di potersi corrompere facilmente (*per dimostrare la propria influenza).
that politician has the advantage of to bribe-SI easily (*to show one's influence)
c. Il museo del campo ha il vantaggio di potersi visitare facilmente (*anche nudi).
the camping museum has the advantage of to be allowed-SI to visit easily (*even naked)

The possibility of control is currently invoked in favor of the hypothesis that the Agent of passives is projected in the syntax. The passive morpheme -en, as well as passivizing SE (in contrast with middle SE), would instantiate syntactically projected Agents (see Jaeggli 1986; Baker et al. 1989; Hoekstra and Roberts 1993b for -en; and Belletti 1982a and Cinque 1988 for SE). This view has been convincingly criticized by Fellbaum and Zribi-Hertz (1989), who argued that phenomena such as control into final clauses or the possibility of Agent-oriented adverbs do not depend on the syntactic realization of the external argument, but instead should be analyzed as being sensitive to the presence of semantically implicit Agents. 31

Important evidence against the projection of Agents in passive configurations comes from control verbs. The Spanish examples in (53) are grammatical (and so are their analogs in (85a–b)), because in Spanish and Italian, SE can be a nominative clitic which, like any other subject clitic, qualifies as a legitimate syntactic controller:

(53)
a. En ciertos estudios basados en fenomenos linguisticos, se ha intentado reformar la historia politica y social.
in certain essays based on linguistic phenomena, SE has tried to reconstruct the political and social history
b. Se espera llegar al final del camino.
SE hopes to arrive at the end of the road

The ungrammaticality of the Romanian examples in (54) can be explained if we assume that (i) passive SE is not a legitimate syntactic controller and (ii) Romanian does not have nominative SE (see section 2.3 above): 32

(54)
a. *In unele studii s-a încercat a reface, pe baza unor fenomene lingvistice, istoria politicǎ şi socialǎ.
in certain essays based on linguistic phenomena, SE-has tried to reconstruct the political and social history
b. *Se sperǎ a ajunge la capǎtul drumului.
SE hopes to arrive at the end of the road.
c. *S-a început a tcedil ine seama de nevoile tuturor.
SE-has started to take into account everybody's needs
d. *S-a promis a respecta dispozi tcedil iile
SE-has promised to obey the instructions
The different guises of agentivity described above can be summarized as follows:

(55)
Verbal passives and middles (unlike adjectival passives and inchoatives) are semantically agentive (semantically imply an Agent-role).
a. Verbal passives (be they analytic or marked by SE), have a syntactically active implicit agent (control into purpose adjunct clauses, subject-oriented adverbs).
b. Middles (exhibiting the property reading) have a syntactically inactive implicit agent (their implicit Agent-role shows no syntactic activity).
(56) Neither analytic nor SE-marked passives can combine with control verbs (try, start, etc.), nor do they license a reflexive pronoun, in contradistinction to nominative SE.

Although Cinque (1988) advocates a unifying analysis of SE, his proposal is in fact based on postulating two homonymical morphemes, marked with distinct Cases: nominative [+arg] SE, which absorbs the external theta-role, and accusative [−arg] SE, which merely suspends it, respectively corresponding to passive and middle SE. This distinction would explain the contrast described in (55a) vs. (55b) and illustrated in (50a) vs (50b) and (51) vs. (52). The hypothesis that passive SE is a nominative clitic functioning as an argument cannot, however, account for the generalization in (56). 33 A more detailed discussion of Cinque's proposal can be found in section 4 below.

subsection.heading: 3.3 Passive SE absorbs the external theta-role in the lexicon
subsection.p: According to some authors, the absorption of the external theta-role by SE takes place in the lexicon, in which case middle-passive SE, although functioning as an Agent, bears no syntactic relation to the subject position. This type of lexical rule is, however, highly problematic. Standard lexical rules affect argument structure, by suppressing or adding a theta-role (cf. passivization and causativization, respectively), but cannot directly assign a given theta-role to a designated lexical item. 34 Theta-roles can be assigned to lexical items only indirectly: a given lexical item is assigned a grammatical function (due to the syntactic position it occupies or to the morphological or abstract Case that it is assigned), and linking rules (lexicon–syntax mapping rules) ensure the relation between grammatical functions (or syntactic positions) and theta-roles.

subsection.heading: 3.4 Middle-passive SE absorbs the external theta-role in the syntax, via a chain with the Spec, IP position
subsection.p: Let us now examine those analyses that rely on the hypothesis that passive SE is a particular type of subject clitic, which takes its external role in the syntax, via a chain with a subject-related position (which, depending on the author, can be Spec, IP; Spec, VP; Spec, vP; or Spec, AgrP), onto which the external role is projected. The numerous implementations of this view vary depending on the Case-features attributed to SE (accusative, nominative, or even dative), the empirical motivation, and the types of accusative SE for which the absorption hypothesis is postulated (most authors assume this analysis for passive SE; certain authors extend it to middle SE).

According to Burzio (1981), middle-passive SE is a particular type of nominative-subject SE, which forms a chain with the (Spec, IP) position. This analysis is confronted with a number of problems, among which is Case-assignment: if SE itself absorbs nominative Case, there is no Case left for the overt DP, corresponding to the externalized internal argument. In order to allow nominative Case on both si and the preverbal DP, Burzio (1986: 47) allows for overlapping chains (see also Cinque 1988), an undesirable assumption. In (57), the chain (gli spaghetti, si), needed for the transfer of nominative Case to si, overlaps with the chain (gli spaghetti, t), needed for theta-role transmission. Precisely because the two chains intersect in the (Spec, IP) position, nominative Case would be assigned to both chains: 35

(57)
Gli spaghettii sii sono già comprati ti.
the spaghettis SI HAVE already bought
‘The spaghettis have already been bought.’

Quite clearly, the assumptions needed in order to allow both SE and the overt DP to take nominative Case (and correlatively be in a CHAIN with Spec, IP) do not belong to core GB theory, but are in fact distortions of GB theory that are merely meant to provide a technical solution for the problems raised by the Burzio–Cinque analysis.

A further, interrelated problem is that the trigger of NP-movement is lost: an affix marked with nominative Case does not absorb accusative Case, which therefore is available for the internal argument, thus voiding the need for NP-movement. Since Cinque wants to preserve the hypothesis that passivization correlates with NP-movement, he provides the following solution (1988: 558–559): the suspension of accusative Case is triggered, due to Burzio's generalization, by the fact that nominative SE suspends/withholds the external theta-role. 36

Another problem is that French (as well as Romanian) lacks nominative SE, and yet has passive and middle SE. This is unexpected within Burzio's assumption, according to which middle and passive SEs are particular instantiations of nominative SE. 37 Burzio (1986: 145–148) concludes his short discussion of French middle-passive SE by acknowledging that it does not show the standard properties of nominative SE; it would be a “particular, unique” manifestation of nominative SE. But then, precisely because Italian and French middle-passives behave on a par, Burzio is led to conclude that Italian has two distinct types of nominative SE: the canonical one, which qualifies as a well-behaved nominative clitic, and is absent in French, and a peculiar one, corresponding to middle-passive SE (in both French and Italian).

Burzio's problematic analysis was adopted, under Cinque's (1988) revision, 38 by the vast majority of GB theorists. Dobrovie-Sorin (1994b, 1998) argued instead that middle and passive SEs are particular instantiations of accusative SE (see section 4 below for alternative analyses of the data brought up by Burzio and Cinque). Here, we will briefly sketch an alternative account of the piece of data illustrated in (58), corresponding to Burzio's (1986: 47, example (69)):
(58) [quei libri]i si andranno . . . a comprare ti

According to Burzio, examples of this kind rely on both object-preposing of quei libri and NP-movement (more precisely, subject raising) of si. Since the NP-movement of si can only apply to the subject clitic si, in contrast to accusative si, Burzio concludes that the si in (58) is a subject si. There is, however, no evidence in favor of the fact that in this example, si has undergone NP-movement. We may alternatively analyze this displacement as being due to Restructuring (Rizzi 1982a), a configuration in which the object clitics generated on the embedded verb end up cliticized on the main verb: 39
(59) Giovanni loi va/viene a prendere ti.
In sum, the position of si in (58) is to be accounted for in the same way as the position of lo in (59), which is consistent with si being accusative rather than nominative.

subsection.heading: 3.5 Middle-passive SE forms a chain with an A-position other than Spec, IP
subsection.p: The proliferation of syntactic positions that characterized late versions of GB theory made it technically possible for the external role of middle-passive verbs to be syntactically projected in positions other than Spec, IP. In their analysis of Dutch middles (which are not marked by a reflexive clitic) Hoekstra and Roberts (1993) propose that the external role is absorbed by a null subject of type pro that occupies (Spec, VP), the VP-internal subject position (see Sportiche 1988 and many others). The advantage of this proposal, which was adapted to Romance middle-passive SE in the subsequent GB and Minimalist literature, would be that the (Spec, IP) position remains available for the Theme to raise to. Note, however, that we must assume that an agentive pro in (Spec, VP) can be bypassed by the Theme-DP on its way to (Spec, IP). This is a locality problem that arises for all versions of this analysis, which essentially postulate that passive SE configurations consist of two chains: the chain of the internal argument, obtained by NP-movement from the object position to (Spec, IP), would co-exist with the chain of the external argument. The exact shape of this second chain differs from one author to the other, varying with the technical changes of the model itself. According to Postma (1995), SE heads the projection of AGRo, 40 and PRO sits in the Spec of this same projection and binds a trace in (Spec, VP):

Postma assumes that this configuration underlies all uses of accusative SE, and he derives the different possible readings from differences in agreement relations: if agreement takes place in IP, we get the reflexive reading; if no agreement takes place, we get the passive reading. The reader is referred to the technical details of this quite complex analysis. Let us simply observe that any analysis that assumes that passives rely on two distinct theta-chains is confronted with the locality problem. Various technical solutions have been proposed, which remain unconvincing.

Minimalist implementations of the same basic analysis are led to stipulate that, unlike overt external arguments (see (61b)), null pronouns corresponding to the external argument (see (61a)) do not block the movement of the internal argument to the subject position (McGinnis 1998): 41

(61)
a. A good guide pro was recommended t by Susanna.
b. *A good guide Susanna was recommended t.

Similarly, the movement of the internal argument would not be blocked by the trace of se in se-passives and se-reflexives (for which McGinnis adopts an unaccusative/passive analysis). The configuration postulated by McGinnis is essentially the same as Potsma's, with AGRoP having been replaced by a light verb projection, notated vP (Chomsky 1995c: chapter 4). The replacement of AGRoP with vP triggers another technical difference: SE can no longer be assumed to head the projection, but may instead be assumed to be generated in the (Spec, vP) position, which in this model is the canonical position for external arguments:

(62)
Pierre se frappe.
‘Pierre slaps himself in the face.’

SE cliticizes to T° as soon as this node is filled by the raised verb, and once SE has cliticized, the object is free to raise to Spec, IP. The fact that null pronouns (see (61a)) and clitic traces allow NP-movement to bypass them, in sharp contrast with overt DPs, is explained on the basis of the assumption that once an NP has cliticized to T, it is no longer accessible for movement to Spec-TP, so this NP and its trace don't count as interveners for Shortest Move.

A still different version of the hypothesis that the external theta-role is syntactically projected in middle-passive configurations can be found in Cardinaletti's (1990) analysis of German middles. According to Cardinaletti, the es that shows up in hier lebt sich es angenehm absorbs the external theta-role. Note that unlike Italian si, German sich is uncontroversially an accusative clitic. Cardinaletti's analysis of German thus winds up postulating that an accusative middle-passivizing morpheme such as sich (i) does not absorb the external theta-role but (ii) does not suspend it either (since this theta-role would be linked to es).

subsection.heading: 3.6 SE absorbs the external theta-role and dative Case
subsection.p: The locality problem discussed above is avoided by a technical implementation due to Guéron (1991), who builds on Kayne's (1988) suggestion that in all its uses, including reflexive SE and subject/nominative SE: (i) SE absorbs the external role; (ii) SE absorbs dative Case; (iii) SE binds/identifies an empty category in a VP-adjoined position. 42 Although this is not explicitly stated, the Kayne–Guéron analysis is meant to solve what was taken to be a severe problem for the analysis of middle-passive SE (and for that of reflexive SE, if the latter is analyzed as unaccusative): if the empty category in object position is the trace of SE, it cannot also be the trace left behind by the A-movement of the internal argument. Note, however, that this problem only arises if one assumes the pronominal analysis of SE, according to which SE necessarily binds a SE-trace in the object position. If instead we adopt Burzio's hypothesis that accusative SE, including middle-passive SE, is a morphological marker, which as such binds no trace, the object position may host the NP-trace of the object raised to the subject position.
The Kayne–Guéron proposal is confronted with several problems. To make the discussion concrete, consider examples such as (63):

(63)
Les pommes se mangent en automne.
the apples SE eat in autumn
‘One eats apples in autumn.’

Since by assumption SE is dative, it is unclear how it can absorb the external role, because this role is not linked to a VP-adjoined position, or to any kind of dative-related position. The answer could be that the external role is of the Experiencer-type. This is indeed compatible with dative-marking, but crucially not with the suspended external role of passives, which is agentive. Guéron suggests that this peculiarity is due to quirky Case, but no empirical evidence supporting this proposal is provided. It is furthermore unclear why a dative-marked reflexive should trigger the absorption of accusative case, which is a defining characteristic of passives. 43

subsection.heading: 3.7 Conclusions
subsection.p: Although standard GB theory (Chomsky 1981) was designed to block it, most GB analyses of passivization postulated the projection of the external role in subject-related positions by modifying those principles of GB that were meant to prevent it. But each of the particular implementations of this hypothesis is confronted with its own problems: passive SE cannot be analyzed as either a nominative clitic or a (possibly accusative) clitic associated with (Spec, IP); nor can we assume passive SE to be a pro occupying (Spec, VP) or the Spec position of some other functional projection.
