This negative result calls for alternative analyses of the empirical evidence adduced in favor of the syntactic projection of the Agent in middle-passive SE constructions: (i) the intricate distribution of middle-passive SE in Italian non-finite clauses; (ii) the correlation between the (preverbal vs. postverbal) position of the subject DP and the meaning (generic/middle/stative vs. eventive passive) of SE-verbs (Ruwet 1972; Raposo and Uriagereka 1996). These two sets of data will be examined in sections 4 and 5 below.

subsection.heading: 4. The distribution of SE in non-finite Italian clauses
subsection.p: Because passivizing SE is illegitimate in control configurations, Burzio (1981, 1986) and all the subsequent literature assumed that passivizing SE needs nominative Case, an assumption that creates theoretical and empirical problems (see sections 4.1.3 and 4.1.4). Dobrovie-Sorin (1998) has provided new solutions to the peculiar distribution of passivizing SE in control infinitivals, based on the view that (i) passivizing SE carries accusative Case and (ii) nominative SE is banned from non-finite clauses (see section 4.2.1). The ungrammaticality of passive SE in control configurations is traced back to three distinct constraints (see section 4.2.2). Finally, it is argued that in Italian non-finite clauses, the SE that appears with unergatives is a passivizing accusative SE (see section 2.4 above).

subsection.heading: 4.1 Cinque's (1988) analysis: two types of nominative SE in Italian
4.1.1 SE with unergatives vs. SE with adjectives, analytic passives, or psych verbs
subsection.p: The contrast between (64) and (65) shows that the class of (presumably) nominative SEs splits in Italian infinitivals: the examples in (64), in which nominative SE combines with unaccusatives, analytic passives, and adjectival predicates, are ungrammatical, whereas the examples in (65), built with unergatives, are grammatical. The examples in this section are borrowed from Cinque (1988), but some of the glosses and the clustering of examples may be different:

(64)
a. *Ritengo non essersi arrivati in sufficiente anticipo. (SE + unaccusatives in Aux-to-Comp)
(I) believe not (to) HAVE-SI arrived sufficiently ahead of time
b. *non essendosi morti in giovane età. (SE + unaccusatives in Aux-to-Comp) not HAVING-SI died young
c. *Sembra essersi arrivati troppo tardi. (SE + unaccusatives in raising configurations) it seems (to) HAVE-SI arrived too late
e. *Sembra non essersi benvenuti qui. (SE + copula in raising configurations) it seems not (to) BE-SI welcome here
f. *Sembra non essersi stati invitati da nessuno. (SE + passive in raising configurations) it seems not HAVE-SI been invited by anybody

(65)
a. Ritengo non essersi provveduto alle sue necessità con la dovuta solerzia.
(I) believe not (to) HAVE-SI taken care of his needs with due zeal.
‘(I) believe his needs have not been taken care of with due zeal.’
b. non essendosi provveduto alle sue necessità con la dovuta solerzia
not HAVING-SI taken care of his needs with due zeal
‘his needs not having been taken care of with due zeal’
c. Sembra non essersi lavorato a sufficienza.
(it) seems not HAVE-SI worked sufficiently
‘It seems that there was not enough work.’

Given this contrast, we may conclude that the SEs that show up in the two classes of examples are of different types. This solution is compatible with several options: we may believe that (i) the two SEs are nominative and accusative, respectively, or (ii) the two SEs are both nominative, but nevertheless distinct. Building on a suggestion by Burzio (1981, 1986), Cinque argues in favor of the second hypothesis, which seems to be supported by the fact that in (65), SE combines with unergatives, a context that was believed to be compatible with nominative SE, but not with accusative SE. This hypothesis seems to be further supported by the contrast between examples such as (65), illustrating Aux-to-Comp and subject-raising configurations, which are known to be compatible with nominative Case assignment, and examples of the type in (66), illustrating configurations relying on arbitrary PRO, in which nominative Case cannot be assigned:

(66)
*Sarebbe meglio lavorarsi un po’ di più.
(it) would be better (to) work SI a bit more
‘It would be better to be worked a bit more.’

According to Burzio (1986) and Cinque (1988), the contrast between (65) and (66) can be explained by assuming that the SE that combines with unergatives needs nominative Case: the examples in (65) are grammatical because SE can get nominative Case (Aux-to-Comp configurations allow nominative Case assignment in Italian infinitivals), whereas the example in (66) is ungrammatical because nominative Case is unavailable in controlled clauses.

subsection.heading: 4.1.2 A passivizing nominative SE
subsection.p: The contrast between (65) and (66) is parallelled by the contrast between (67) and (68), which shows that passive SE is allowed in Aux-to-Comp and subject-raising contexts, but disallowed in control configurations:

(67)
a. Ritengo non essersi ancora scoperto il vero colpevole. (Aux-to-Comp)
[I] believe not to HAVE-SI yet discovered the true culprit
‘I believe the true culprit has not yet been discovered.’
b. non essendosi ancora scoperto il vero colpevole (Aux-to-Comp)
not HAVING-SI yet discovered the true culprit
‘the true culprit not having yet been discovered’
c. Sembra non essersi ancora scoperto il vero colpevole. (Subject raising)
(it) seems not (to) HAVE-SI yet discovered the true culprit
‘It seems that the true culprit has not yet been discovered.’

(68)
Control configurations:
a. *Sarebbe meglio scoprirsi il colpevole.
(it) would be better (to) discover SI the culprit
‘It would be better for the culprit to be discovered.’
b. *Quei prigionierii vorrebero [PROi essersi già liberati ei].
those prisoners would want have SI already released
‘Those prisoners would want to have been already released.’

Although passive SE is compatible with an analysis in terms of accusative SE, the contrast between (67) – where nominative case can be assigned – and (68) – where nominative Case cannot be assigned – was interpreted by Burzio (1986) and Cinque (1988) as indicating that passive SE needs nominative Case, on a par with the SE that combines with unergatives (see again examples (65) vs. (66)).

Let us now be more specific about the details of Cinque's analysis: (i) two distinct nominative SEs are postulated, which are distinguished by different choices for the feature ±arg(ument); (ii) the SE that combines with unergatives (see (65)) may be either +arg or −arg, whereas the SE that combines with the copula, passives, unaccusatives, etc. (see (64)) can only be marked as −arg; (iii) −arg SE is disallowed in those configurations in which no overt AGR morpheme is present (hence the ungrammaticality of (64)).

(69)
Cinque's (1988) typology:
a. −arg [nom] impersonal SE (SE + copula, SE + unaccusatives, SE + passives, SE + unergatives)
b. +arg [nom] passivizing SE (SE + transitives, SE + unergatives)
c. −arg [acc] ‘pure’ passivizing SE (Middle SE)

subsection.heading: 4.1.3 Theoretical problems with the ±arg(ument) distinction
subsection.p: As presented by Cinque himself, the ±arg distinction is an attempt to solve a theoretical problem, which had been previously noted by Burzio (1986: 45f.), Belletti (1982a: fns. 21, 37, Appendix), and Manzini (1986), concerning examples such as (70):

(70)
Si parte.
‘One leaves.’

The verb partire ‘to leave’ belongs to the unaccusative class, and as such assigns a theta-role to the [NP, V′] position, and leaves [Spec, IP] with no theta-role. On the assumption that si is an argument subject clitic base-generated in Infl (or in some Infl-related clitic position) that can take its theta-role only from the Spec, IP position, examples such as (70) violate the Theta-Criterion at D-structure. Cinque solves this problem by assuming that the si that appears in (71) is not an argument (hence the feature [−arg] that would characterize it). Compare an example such as (71):

(71)
Si dorme.
‘One sleeps.’

Since dormire ‘to sleep’ assigns a theta-role to the Spec, IP position at D-structure, it may combine with a +arg si. But note that under Cinque's analysis, dormire may also combine with a −arg si, on a par with partire. In other words, si dorme is systematically ambiguous in Italian, depending on the nature of si, whereas si parte unambiguously relies on a −arg nominative si.

Dobrovie-Sorin (1998) observes that the theoretical problem invoked by Burzio, Belletti, Manzini, and Cinque in connection with si in fact extends to subject clitics in general. Should we then assume a systematic ambiguity for subject clitics in general (cf. in particular the subject clitics of Italian dialects), on a par with the ambiguity that Cinque assumes for si? More concretely, should we assume that subject clitics may be either +arg or −arg when they combine with transitives or unergatives, but only −arg when they combine with unaccusatives? 44 Cinque does not go in this direction, and his implicit answer to the problem of subject clitics is that they should be assumed to be −arg elements, regardless of the type of verb with which they combine. It is important to stress that Cinque's −arg feature should not be interpreted as notating expletive clitics, as opposed to referential clitics, but rather as saying that nominative clitics (and clitics in general) fall outside the argument/non-argument distinction, which is relevant only for elements that occupy A-positions.

We are thus led to conclude that the [−arg] feature need not be stipulated: it is the unmarked option for clitics in general; [+arg] nominative SE, on the other hand, is an element that does not fall under the general characterization of clitics. Cinque assumes [+arg] si to be related to an A-position that is assigned a theta-role at D-structure, but is filled with an expletive at S-structure. Such a discrepancy between the clitic and its trace, which is unprecedented for clitics, brings to mind the current characterization of passive morphemes in general and middle-passive si in particular: si absorbs (or rather suspends) the external theta-role, and as a consequence the subject position is occupied by an expletive. In sum, the [+arg] feature of si, which is found with no other clitic, can be viewed as a label for passive si. Since passive morphemes cannot be marked with nominative Case, we are led to conclude that Cinque's +arg nominative SE is in reality a passivizing SE that absorbs accusative Case. The only genuine nominative SE is Cinque's −arg nominative SE. We thus end up with only two basic distinct types of SE, accusative and nominative. 45

subsection.heading: 4.1.4 Empirical problems
subsection.p: Cinque's proposal is also confronted by several empirical problems:

(72)
a. The hypothesis that [+arg] nominative SE is a passivizer 46 is problematic, since the occurrence of a nominative clitic marked with the external theta-role is incompatible with the passivization phenomenon. To make them compatible, one would have to allow for the double assignment of nominative Case or for overlapping CHAINS, which are undesirable on general grounds (see section 3.4. above).
b. Passive SE-verbs agree with the overt DP, on a par with reflexives and other types of accusative SE-verbs. Compare −arg [nom] SE, which triggers lack of agreement between the verb and the overt DP.
c. Passive SE cannot co-occur with an accusative-marked argument. This is expected if SE itself is [acc], but not if it is [nom].

In what follows, these problems will be illustrated with examples borrowed from Cinque (1988) himself. Crucial for the analysis of the data is the contrast between SE-verbs in Italian finite and non-finite clauses: whereas a truly nominative SE can appear in Italian finite clauses (see section 2.3 above), it is ungrammatical in Italian non-finite clauses. The contrast between Italian finite and non-finite clauses is parallelled by the contrast between Italian and Romanian finite SE-verbs. This is predicted by the hypothesis that Romanian does not have nominative SE.

subsection.heading: 4.1.4.1 Verbal agreement
subsection.p: Because the overt DP of a middle-passive SE is a subject, it triggers agreement with the verb. With nominative SE instead, the verb is in the third person singular. In Italian infinitivals, verb agreement with the postverbal NP is obligatory (the agreement can only be checked here on the past participle, since in non-finite clauses the auxiliary verb is not inflected for number and person), which supports the analysis in terms of a middle-passive SE:

(73)
a. *Ritengo essersi venduto pochi automobili.
(I) esteem (to) have SI sold (sing.) few cars
b. *?essendosi venduto pochi automobili
having SI sold (sing.) few cars

(74)
a. Ritengo essersi venduti pochi automobili.
(I) esteem (to) have-SI sold (pl.) few cars
‘I esteem to have been sold (pl.) few cars.’
b. essendosi venduti pochi automobili
having SI sold (pl.) few cars
‘having been sold (pl.) few cars’
(examples borrowed from Cinque 1988: (79–80))
As expected, the agreement pattern found in Italian non-finite si constructions also characterizes Romanian finite si constructions, because they can only rely on middle-passive si:

(75)
a. *În aceastǎ universitate se predǎ ştiin tcedil ele umane.
in this university SE teaches (sing.) the humanities
b. În aceastǎ universitate se predau ştiin tcedil ele umane.
in this university SE teach (plur.) the humanities
‘In this university are taught the humanities.’

subsection.heading: 4.1.4.2 The distribution of accusative clitics
subsection.p: Another piece of evidence showing that passive SE in Italian infinitivals is [acc] is provided by the distribution of accusative clitics. While [nom] impersonal SE is compatible with accusative clitics (see example (35d)), middle-passive SE is not:

(76)
a. *Ritengo esserlesi vendute ad un prezzo eccessivo.
(I) esteem (to) have-them-SI sold at an excessive price
b. *essendolesi vendute ad un prezzo eccessivo
having-them-SI sold at an excessive price
(examples borrowed from Cinque 1988: (81–82))
The same type of ungrammaticality arises in Romanian finite clauses:

(77)
*(ştiin tcedil ele umane) le se predǎ în aceastǎ universitate
(the humanities) them SE teach in this university

subsection.heading: 4.1.4.3 L’uno l’altro, floating of tutti
subsection.p: Impersonal [nom] SE can serve as an antecedent for l’uno l’altro:

(78)
Si era parlato l’uno con l’altro. Italian
SI had spoken with each other
‘We/they had spoken with each other.’
But l’uno l’altro is disallowed in Italian infinitivals (and in Romanian finite clauses):

(79)
a. (Io non c’ero, ma) *deve/sembra essersi parlato l’uno con l’altro. Italian
‘(I wasn't there, but) (it) must/seems (to) have SI spoken with each other.’
b. *Ritenevo essersi parlato l’uno con l’altro.
‘I deemed (to) have SI spoken with each other.’
c. *non essendosi affatto parlato l’uno con l’altro
‘not having SI at all spoken with each other’

(80)
*S-a vorbit unul cu altul. Romanian
‘SI has spoken with each other.’

The observed ungrammaticalities can be understood if we assume that in Italian infinitivals, the SE that combines with unergatives can only be a middle-passive accusative SE (just as in Romanian finite clauses; see (82) and section 2.4 above), which induces a chain of the type (pro, e), which is assigned the theta-role corresponding to a cognate object. But cognate objects are not legitimate antecedents of l’uno l’altro, hence the ungrammaticality of (79a–c) in Italian and (80) in Romanian.

The same behavior is found with the quantifier tutti: it allows impersonal [nom] SE as an antecedent (see (81)) but not the [acc] passive SE, which occurs in Italian embedded infinitivals (see (82)) and in Romanian finite clauses (see (83)):

(81)
Si è reagito a sproposito tutti. Italian
SI has reacted off the point all
‘We all reacted off the point.’

(82)
a. *?Sembra essersi reagito a sproposito tutti. Italian
‘(It) seems (to) have SI reacted off the point all.’
b. *?Ritiene essersi reagito a sproposito tutti.
‘(He) believes (to) have SI reacted off the point all.’
c. *?essendosi reagito a sproposito tutti
‘Having SI reacted off the point all’

(83)
*S-a reac tcedil ionat prost to tcedil;i. Romanian
‘SE-has reacted badly all.’

subsection.heading: 4.1.4.4 Control
subsection.p: In Italian non-finite clauses, si cannot combine with control verbs:

(84)
*Ritengo non essersi promesso di ottemperare alle disposizioni.
‘(I) believe not (to) HAVE-SI promised to obey the instructions.’
This is still another context in which Italian non-finite clauses contrast with Italian finite clauses (85) and are parallel to Romanian finite clauses ((54), repeated here as (86)):

(85)
a. In certi studi basati su fenomeni linguistici, si è cercato di ricostruire la storia politica e sociale.
in certain essays based on linguistic phenomena, SE-has tried to reconstruct the political and social history
b. Se espera llegar al final del camino.
SE hopes to arrive at the end of the road
c. Si è cominciato a prendere in considerazione le esigenze di tutti.
SE-has started to take into account everybody's needs
d. Si è promesso di seguire le istruzioni.
SE-has promised to obey the instructions

(86)
a. *In unele studii s-a încercat a reface, pe baza unor fenomene lingvistice, istoria politicǎ şi socialǎ.
In certain essays based on linguistic phenomena, SE-has tried to reconstruct the political and social history
b. *Se sperǎ a ajunge la capǎtul drumului.
SE hopes to arrive at the end of the road
c. *S-a început a tcedil;ine seama de nevoile tuturor.
SE-has started to take into account everybody's needs
d. *S-a promis a respecta dispozi tcedil;iile
SE-has promised to obey the instructions

The data in (84) are surprising under Cinque's (1988) analysis relying on nominative SE, but expected if nominative SE is disallowed in Italian non-finite clauses; in examples such as (84), si can only be analyzed as a middle-passive accusative si, which is not a legitimate syntactic controller. 47

subsection.heading: 4.2.1 Nominative clitics and agreement features
subsection.p: According to Dobrovie-Sorin (1998), Cinque's +arg nominative SE is a passivizing accusative SE. Because passivization cannot apply to the copula, passives or unaccusatives, the examples in (64) cannot be analyzed as relying on a passivizing accusative SE, but could only rely on nominative SE (which is free to combine with any kind of verb). However, this possibility is itself ruled out, because nominative si is not allowed in Italian non-finite clauses, an impossibility that Dobrovie-Sorin attributes to the empirical generalization stated in (87): 48
(87) Nominative clitics must be identified by overt subject agreement morphemes. 49

This generalization explains why examples of the type in (64) are ungrammatical. The examples in (65), on the other hand, are grammatical, because they can be analyzed as relying on a passivizing accusative SE (which can combine with unergatives; see section 2.4 above).

subsection.heading: 4.2.2 Middle-passive SE in control infinitivals
subsection.p: The main empirical data that led Burzio (1986) and Cinque (1988) to believe that passivizing SE needed nominative Case was the ban on passivizing SE in control configurations ((68), repeated here as (88–89), and (66), repeated here as (90)):

(88)
*Sarebbe meglio scoprirsi il colpevole.
(it) would be better (to) discover SI the culprit
‘It would be better for the culprit to be discovered.’

(89)
*Quei prigionierii vorrebero [PROi essersi già liberati ei].
those prisoners would want have SI already released
‘Those prisoners would want to have been already released.’

(90)
*Sarebbe meglio lavorarsi un po’ di più.
(it) would be better (to) work SI a bit more
‘It would be better to be worked a bit more.’

Following Burzio (1986: 44), Cinque (1988) attributes the ungrammaticality of (88–90) to a violation of the Case filter: si requires nominative Case, which cannot be assigned in control configurations. Compare Aux-to-Comp contexts (see (67)), in which nominative Case can be assigned. This explanation is not available within Dobrovie-Sorin's (1998) analysis, according to which the si in (88–90) is marked with accusative Case. Dobrovie-Sorin proposes that the ungrammaticality shown in (88–90) is due to three distinct constraints, none of which requires si itself to be marked with nominative Case.

subsection.heading: 4.2.2.1 Case
subsection.p: Case assignment is relevant only in example (88): il colpevole is an overt DP, which as such needs Case. But nominative Case cannot be assigned in this type of Italian infinitivals; il colpevole cannot take accusative Case either, because it is si itself that needs accusative Case.

subsection.heading: 4.2.2.2 A semantic constraint on control
subsection.p: Nominative Case is not needed in (89), since there is no lexical DP in the infinitival clause. Dobrovie-Sorin suggests that the relevant factor is a semantic constraint, which is in fact suggested by Cinque's (1988) own observation that control is compatible with si if the property reading is forced:

(91)
a. La luce gialla ha il vantaggio di vedersi bene anche nella nebbia più fitta.
the yellow light has the advantage of see SI well even in the thickest fog
‘The yellow light has the advantage of being able to be seen even in the thickest fog.’
b. Certe lingue hanno la proprietà di impararsi con più facilità di altre.
certain languages have the property of acquire SI more easily than others.
‘Certain languages have the property of being more easily learnable than others.’
(= Cinque 1988: (187a–b))

According to Cinque, the examples in (91) are grammatical because the property reading relies on middle si, which is accusative. Compare the ungrammaticality of (89), constructed with an impersonal passive si, which according to Cinque requires nominative Case. Since there is, however, no conclusive evidence in favor of the Case distinction between passive and middle si, Dobrovie-Sorin assumes only one type of passivizing si, marked with accusative Case, which allows either an eventive passive or a middle reading, depending on the position of the overt DP-argument (see section 5 below). Examples such as (89) are ungrammatical because the verb volere ‘want’ requires the embedded clause to refer to a particular event, but the eventive passive reading of SE-verbs is blocked in controlled clauses. This constraint on the reading of SE-verbs is a particular case of a broader empirical generalization, to be examined in section 5 below: the eventive passive reading is blocked if the subject DP sits in Spec, IP.

subsection.heading: 4.2.2.3 Passive SE unergatives and the argument status of PRO
subsection.p: We are left with (90), repeated as (92a). Dobrovie-Sorin's explanation relies on the parallellism with (92b), the ungrammaticality of which is itself comparable to that of (93a–c) in English:

(92)
a. *Sarebbe meglio [PROi lavorarsii ei un po’ di più].
(it) would be better [PROi (to) work SIi ei a bit more]
b. *Sarebbe meglio [PRO piovere un po’ di più].
(it) would be better [PRO (to) rain a bit more]

(93)
a. *PRO to rain tomorrow would be a tragedy.
b. *PRO to arrive a man would be marvelous.
(cf. For there to arrive a man . . . )
c. *PRO being likely that. . . , we didn't go.
(cf. It being likely that . . . , we didn't go.)
d. PRO to arrive late would be an offense.
(cf. For us/you . . . to arrive late . . . )
According to Chomsky (1981: 325–327) and Rizzi (1982), the ungrammaticality of (93a–c) is due to the generalization stated in (94):
(94) [A chain headed by] arbitrary [non-controlled] PRO is necessarily an argument.

Examples (93a–c), as well as (92b), are ungrammatical because weather verbs and impersonal constructions must be constructed with quasi-argumental and expletive subjects, respectively, which conflicts with the argument status of PRO (see (94)). Compare the example in (93d), which is grammatical, because there PRO takes a fully referential reading.

This analyis also accounts for (92a): the (PRO, e) chain on which (92) relies counts as an argument, and this conflicts with the selectional requirements imposed by middle-passive unergatives (cognate objects are not fully referential arguments).
This account predicts the grammaticality of middle-passive si unergatives in Aux-to-Comp configurations (65a–b), repeated here as (95)):

(95)
a. Ritengo non essersi provveduto alle sue necessità con la dovuta solerzia.
(I) believe not (to) HAVE-SI taken care of his needs with due zeal
‘(I) believe his needs have not been taken care of with due zeal.’
b. non essendosi provveduto alle sue necessità con la dovuta solerzia
not HAVING-SI taken care of his needs with due zeal
‘his needs not having been taken care of with due zeal’

Since nominative Case can be assigned here (by the Aux raised to Comp), these examples can be analyzed as relying on chains of the type (pro, e), which are not subject to the constraint in (94), and therefore can function as cognate objects, licensed by the quasi theta-role assigned by unergatives to their objects.
The distribution of SE unergatives is thus completely parallel to the distribution of weather verbs as described and analyzed by Rizzi (1982):

(96)
Essendo piovuto per tutto il pomeriggio, non siamo usciti.
‘Having rained for the whole afternoon, (we) didn't go out.’

(97)
Suppongo [esser molto improbabile che Mario ci aiuti].
‘(I) consider (it) (to) be very unlikely that Mario help us.’

In sum, the fact that si Vunerg sequences are allowed in Aux-to-Comp contexts and disallowed in control configurations is not due to the fact that si needs nominative Case, but rather to the interpretive constraint in (94), which holds for PRO as opposed to pro.

subsection.heading: 5 The interpretation of SE-verbs and the position of their subject
subsection.p: In this section we will examine a well-known constraint on the passive reading of SE: it can only obtain in those contexts in which the subject (corresponding to the underlying internal argument) occupies a VP-internal position; in case it occupies the canonical subject position, the passive reading is unavailable, the only possible interpretation being the middle reading. We will show that this generalization, established for French by Stéfanini (1962) and Ruwet (1972), subsumes Raposo and Uriagereka's (1996) generalization regarding European Portuguese. We will, however, question Raposo and Uriagereka's explanation, which was based on Cinque's (1988) hypothesis that passive SE is a subject-like clitic.

subsection.heading: 5.1 French: the choice between the middle and the passive readings depends on the S-structure position of the overt argument
subsection.p: Stéfanini (1962) and Ruwet (1972) have established that:
(98) French SE-verbs with preverbal subjects allow the middle reading, but cannot take the eventive passive reading (see (99)), 50 which is allowed only in il-impersonals (see (100)).

(99)
a. Ce livre s’achète par correspondence.
this book SI buys by mail
‘This book can be bought by mail.’
b. *Ce livre s’est acheté hier.
this book SI HAS bought yesterday
‘This book was bought yesterday.’
c. *Les prisonniers se libéreront la semaine prochaine/le plus rapidement possible.
the prisoners SE will release next week/as soon as possible
‘The prisoners will be released next week/as soon as possible.’

(100)
a. Il se boira beaucoup de vin ce soir.
it SE will drink a lot of wine this evening
‘A lot of wine will be drunk this evening.’
b. Il s’est bu beaucoup de whisky à la réception.
it SE HAS drunk much whisky at the reception
‘A lot of whisky was drunk at the reception.’
The eventive meaning is indicated by the compatibility with temporal adverbials and the incompatibility with the manner adverbs characteristic of middles (Obenauer 1970: 62):

(100)
c. * Il se reboise pas mal de terrains difficilement.
it SE reforests quite a number of grounds difficultly
‘Quite a number of grounds are difficult to reforest.’
Since the postverbal DP of French il-impersonals occupies the object position, the French data can be summarized as follows:

(101)
a. Subject DP in Spec, IP ⇒ middle and habitual passive readings of [acc] SE.
b. subject DP in VP-internal position ⇒ eventive passive reading of [acc] SE.

subsection.heading: 5.2.1 Raposo and Uriagereka's (1996) generalization
subsection.p: Raposo and Uriagereka (1996) established that in European Portuguese (eventive-)passive configurations, the preverbal subject is not in (Spec, IP), but instead occupies a left-peripheral position (Topic or Focus, depending on the inherent properties of the DP): 51

(102)
a. [specIPDP] [I′ se V . . . ]] ⇒ *passive SE.
b. [specTopPDP] [IP [I′ se V . . . ]] ⇒ OK passive SE.

Inflected infinitivals provide evidence in favor of this analysis. Thus, both an analytic passive and a SE-passive may occur as inflected infinitives with the agreeing DP in the postverbal position (all the following examples are European Portuguese):

(103)
a. Vai ser difficil [pro serem aceites [os documentos]]. (analytic passive)
will be difficult to-be-3pl accepted the documents
‘It will be difficult for the documents to be accepted.’ (SE-passive)
b. Vai ser difficil [pro aceitarem-se [os documentos]].
will be difficult (to)-accept-3pl-SE the documents
‘It will be difficult for the documents to be accepted.’
However, an eventive-passive SE, in contrast with analytic passives, is ungrammatical if the DP is in the preverbal position:

(104)
a. Vai ser difficil [[os documentos]i serem aceites ti ]. (analytic passive)
will be difficult the documents to-be-3pl accepted
‘It will be difficult for the documents to be accepted.’
b. *Vai ser difficil [[os documentos]i aceitarem-se ti ]. (SE-passive)
will be difficult the documents SE-to-accept-3pl
In embedded infinitivals, preverbal subjects can only occupy the Spec, IP position, since the Spec, Top position is not available there:

(105)
*Vai ser dificil [[esses documentos], os tribunais aceitarem(-nos) ec].
(it) will be difficult those documents, the courts (to) accept-3pl(-them)
‘It will be difficult those documents, for the courts to accept (them).’
Since the Spec, IP position, blocks the eventive-passive reading of SE-verbs (by virtue of the generalization in (102a)), this reading is unavailable in (104b).

Another relevant context is Aux-to-Comp: the position immediately on the right of Aux is of necessity Spec, IP, which can be occupied by the subject of analytic passives, but not by the subject of SE passives:

(106)
a. Eu penso [teremj[[os presos]i tj sido fuzilados ti]]. (copula passive)
(I) think (to)-have-3pl the prisoners been shot
‘I think the prisoners were shot.’
b. *Eu penso [terem-sej [[os presos]j tj fuzilado tj ]. (passive SE)
(I) think (to) have-3pl-SE the prisoners shot

Raposo and Uriagereka furthermore show that in eventive SE passives, the Topic DP cannot bind a trace in (Spec, IP). The argument relies on the distribution of bare NPs. As is well known, in Romance pro-drop languages, bare NPs (BNPs) cannot occupy the preverbal subject position (Spec, IP):

(107)
a. O Nestor compra salsichas no talho Sanzot. (BNP in object position)
the Nestor buys sausages at-the butcher-shop Sanzot
‘Nestor buys sausages at the Sanzot butcher-shop.’
b. *Salsichas sao compradas no talho Sanzot. (BNP in Spec, IP)
sausages are bought at-the butcher-shop Sanzot
‘Sausages are bought at the Sanzot butcher-shop.’
c. *Salsichas custam caro no talho Sanzot. (BNP in Spec, IP)
sausages cost expensive at-the butcher-shop Sanzot
‘Sausages are expensive at the Sanzot butcher-shop.’

Dislocated bare NPs are allowed only if they bind the object position (see (108a)). The ungrammaticality of (108b–c) indicates that the dislocated subjects (marked by the comma intonation) of analytic passives and of unergatives bind a trace in [Spec, Infl], which is illegitimate:

(108)
a. Salsichas, o Nestor compra ec no talho Sanzot. (trace in object position)
sausages, the Nestor buys at-the butcher-shop Sanzot
‘Sausages, Nestor buys at the Sanzot butcher-shop.’
b. *Salsichas, ec sao compradas t no talho Sanzot. (intermediate trace in Spec, IP)
sausages, are bought at-the butcher-shop Sanzot
‘Sausages, (they) are bought at the Sanzot butcher-shop.’
c. *Salsichas, ec custam caro no talho Sanzot. (intermediate trace in Spec, IP)
sausages, cost expensive at-the butcher-shop Sanzot
‘Sausages, (they) are expensive at the Sanzot butcher-shop.’
The grammaticality of (109b) indicates that the dislocated subject of SE passives does not necessarily bind a trace in (Spec, IP), but may be directly coindexed with the object position:

(109)
a. Vendem-se salsichas no talho Sanzot. (BNP in obj position)
sell-3pl-SE sausages at-the butcher-shop Sanzot
‘Sausages are sold at the Sanzot butcher-shop.’
b. Salsichas, vendem-se ec no talho Sanzot.
sausages, sell-3pl-SE at-the butcher-shop Sanzot.
‘Sausages, (they) are sold at the Sanzot butcher-shop.’

Further evidence in favor of Raposo and Uriagereka's generalization is provided by parasitic gaps (which we do not review here), and by the position of the subject DP relative to other left-peripheral DPs. The left periphery of European Portuguese contains at least three positions, as indicated in (110). Each one of these slots may, but need not, be instantiated:
(110) [specTopP def DP . . . [specFocP wh-phrases . . . [specIP canonical subject]]]

With the eventive-passive SE, the preverbal subject cannot occupy the Spec, IP position (see (111b)); it is either in [Spec, Top], as in (111a), or in (Spec, Foc), as in (112), depending on whether it is a definite DP or a focused constituent (wh-phrase, emphatic operator):

(111)
a. [specTopP[Esses livros]i [specFocP[so numa loja]k [IP/I′ se vendem eci eck]]].
those books only at-one store SE-sell-3pl
‘Those books only at a (particular) store are sold.’
b. *[specFP[So numa loja]k[specIP [esses livros]i se vendem eci eck]].
only at-on store those books SE-sell-3pl

(112)
a. [specTopP A Maria, [spec FP [quantos presentes]i [spec IP [se deram eci]]]]?
to-the Mary, how-many presents SE-gave-3pl
‘To Mary, how many presents were given?’
b. [specTopP A Maria, [specFP[muitos presentes]i [specIP [se deram eci]]]].
to-the Mary, many presents SE-gave-3pl
‘To Mary, many presents were given.’
The example in (111c) shows that the subject of analytic passives can occupy Spec, IP:

(111)
c. [specFPSo numa loja [specIP esses livros sao vendidos]].
only at one store those books are sold (subject of copula passive SE in Spec, IP)

In sum, Raposo and Uriagereka provide clear evidence showing that the preverbal subject of eventive-passive SE does not sit in (Spec, IP), nor does it bind a trace in (Spec, IP). It sits in a left-peripheral position and entertains a direct relation with a VP-internal position. This behavior of passive SE contrasts with analytic passives, as well as with SE-reflexives.

subsection.heading: 5.2.2 Middle SE
subsection.p: The behavior of middle SE was not examined by Raposo and Uriagereka. One may simply guess that middle SE contrasts with passive SE and behaves on a par with reflexives. By using the tests provided by Raposo and Uriagereka themselves, it can indeed be shown that middle SE allows its subject to sit in Spec, IP.

In contrast with eventive-passive SE, middle SE allows its subject to be in the preverbal position in inflected infinitivals, and this position can only be analyzed as being Spec, IP (compare example (104b)):

(113)
a. vai ser dificil esta luz ver-se de longe
(it) will be difficult this light see(inflected)- SE from afar
b. vai ser dificil este lindo vestido lavar-se facilmente
(it) will be difficult this beautiful dress wash-SE easily
(examples provided by Joao Costa, p.c.)

Note furthermore that the preverbal subject of middle SE may occur to the right of an extracted adjunct, in which case it can only sit in (Spec, IP). Middle SE thus patterns with reflexives and analytic passives and contrasts with eventive passive SE:

(114)
a. [specTopEm que momento do espectáculo] [specIPa luz] se viu bem?
at what moment of the show the light SE saw well
(Joao Costa, p.c.)
b. [specTopEm que momento da operaçao] [specIPos especialistas] se consultaram?
at what moment of the operation the specialists consulted each other
≠ at what moment of the operation the specialists were consulted
Given the data just reviewed, Raposo and Uriagereka's generalization should be revised as follows:

(115)
Revision of Raposo and Uriagereka's generalization:
a. [specIPDP] [I′ se V . . . []] ⇒ OK middle, *eventive-passive
b. [specTopPDP] [IP [I′ se V . . . []]] ⇒ OK eventive passive

subsection.heading: 5.3 A unifying analysis of European Portuguese and French
subsection.p: The data in European Portuguese summarized in (115a–b) bring to mind Ruwet's generalization (see (101)):
(116) Just as in French, a preverbal DP sitting in (Spec, IP) triggers the middle/generic reading of passive SE constructions. The eventive-passive reading is blocked.

Because European Portuguese is a pro-drop language, preverbal subjects do not necessarily sit in Spec, IP, but may be in Spec, Top or Spec, Focus instead. These positions do not induce the interpretive constraint characteristic of Spec, IP. We may thus conclude that French and European Portuguese illustrate two particular instantiations of one and the same constraint on passive SE configurations.

subsection.heading: 5.3.1 Raposo and Uriagereka's explanation
subsection.p: Raposo and Uriagereka's explanation basically amounts to the idea that the Spec, IP position is made unavailable by the eventive-passive SE. Raposo and Uriagereka follow Cinque (1988) in assuming that the eventive-passive SE is marked as +arg and is an ‘[NP, IP]’ clitic, which as such fills – at some point in the derivation – the [NP, IP] position: SE goes to (Spec, v′) and from there to (Spec, IP), thus rendering this position unavailable for the internal argument to raise to. This account is problematic insofar as it basically amounts to assuming that a passivizing morpheme, here SE, is a subject clitic (see sections 3.4 and 4 above).

The contrast between the middle and the eventive-passive reading is not explicitly brought up by Raposo and Uriagereka. Within their account, the behavior of middle SE can only be analyzed as being due to its inherent features: in contrast with passive SE, middle SE does not need to go to Spec, IP. Thus, in order to account for the contrast between passive and middle SE, Raposo and Uriagereka would have to postulate lexical homophony: passive SE and middle SE would be two inherently distinct elements, much as in Cinque (1988). 52 The problem is that there is no evidence – other than the data we try to explain – in favor of a distinction between passive and middle SE. In particular, they both trigger ‘agreement with the object’ (this is Raposo and Uriagereka's term, which in fact refers to the overt subject, corresponding to an underlying Theme), which is the criterion that Raposo and Uriagereka choose for distinguishing eventive-passive (their ‘indefinite’) SE from the ‘impersonal’ (i.e., nominative) SE.

subsection.heading: 5.3.2 An alternative line of inquiry
subsection.p: Dobrovie-Sorin (2004, forthcoming) proposes an explanation based on the idea that the ‘syntactic activity’ of the Agent (which is necessary for the passive reading to obtain) of SE-verbs is possible only if the internal argument occupies the object position. Under this view, the passive reading of accusative SE is blocked not because passive SE itself goes to Spec, IP, but rather because this position must remain empty in order for the Agent to be present at Logical Form.

subsection.heading: NOTES

p.span: 1 To this day, Kayne (1975) and Burzio (1986) remain the best references on the problem stated in (i), both for the detail of the empirical description and for insights regarding the analysis. For (iii) the reader is referred to Giorgi (1991).

2 Zubizarreta (1987) and Belletti (1982) distinguish reflexives from middle-passive SE: the latter, but not the former, would absorb the external theta-role. Burzio (1986) analyzes middle-passive SE as a particular instantiation of subject/nominative SE. Cinque adopts this analysis for impersonal and habitual passive SE (Dans cette maison, la Bible se lit tous les jours ‘In this house, the Bible SE reads every day’), but departs from Burzio in assuming that the property interpretation of middles (Ce livre se lit facilement ‘This book SE-reads easily’) relies on accusative SE. Within Cinque's typology, impersonal passives (including habitual passives) rely on a nominative +arg SE, whereas middles rely on an accusative −arg SE.

3 The morphological identity shown by passives, anticausatives, and reflexives is widespread across unrelated language families, such as Indo-European, Uto-Aztecan, Athapaskan, Turkic, Ethiopian Semitic, and Dravidian (Haspelmath 1987, 1990; Kemmer 1993; Geniušenė 1987).

4 Perlmutter's (1978) unaccusatives were called ‘ergatives’ by Burzio (1981, 1986). Because it may cause confusion (by unduly bringing to mind ‘ergative’ languages), this terminology will be avoided here.
5 In order to simplify the glosses, the verb être ‘be’ will be translated as have whenever it functions as a perfect auxiliary.
6 For the claim that unergatives and unaccusatives can be distinguished in terms of internal/external causation see also Levin and Rappaport (1995), who attribute the main insight to Smith (1970).

7 Labelle further assumes that in SE-inchoatives the external role (the one to which is attributed ‘responsibility’ for the change) is discharged by SE itself, which would be generated in the (Spec, VP) position, leaving the Spec, IP slot available for the externalization of the internal argument (1992: 395). This proposal, which suffers from the problems brought up in section 3 below, is not crucial for Labelle's main proposal.

8 Crucial to Burzio's view is the idea that SE is not a pronoun, but rather an unaccusativity marker. The ‘affixal’ nature of SE is less central: being an unaccusativity marker does not force a given element to be an affix (completely bound morpheme), but is compatible with it being a clitic (‘semi-bound’ morpheme, or ‘syntactic affix’ in Anderson's 1992 terms), or a weak pronoun (cf. Dutch zich-anaphors). Conversely, affixes (e.g., agreement morphemes on the verb) may function as pronouns, by virtue of binding an empty category of type pro.
9 In Italian, the embedded verb may be interpreted as reflexive in the absence of SE:

subsection.p: The fact that SE cannot surface in Italian examples such as (i–ii) thus seems to be due not to a constraint on the compatibility between the syntactic operations underlying causatives and reflexives, but rather to a morphological constraint on SE-placement in Italian causatives. Pesetsky (1995: 99–100) suggests that the disappearance of SE in Italian causatives and the disappearance of SE in nominalizations (in all Romance languages) are due to the same constraint. The generalization would be that the lexicalization of the +reflexive feature is blocked by derivational morphemes. French and Spanish causatives, which allow reflexives, would have to be analyzed as syntactic causatives, whereas their Italian counterparts would be morphological causatives.

p.span: 10 According to Burzio (1986: 140, 406), the verb be as a perfect-marker is triggered, in both French and Italian, by the co-indexation relation that holds between SE and the subject position. Because both accusative SE and dative SE are co-indexed with the subject position, be is used as a perfect marker in both cases. Note, however, that dative SE differs from accusative SE in not allowing agreement on the past participle, despite be-selection. With accusative SE, past participle agreement is obligatory (compare the optional agreement triggered by accusative clitics):

row.entry: Mary SE HAS described-femin. to the children
Mary her has described-femin. to the children
Marie s’est dit/*dite qu’elle n’aimait plus Jean.
Mary SE-HAS said-unmarked/*said-femin that she no longer loved John
Marie s’est maudite/*maudit d’avoir laisser mourir Jean.
Mary SE-HAS blamed-unmarked/*blamed-femin. for having let die John

subsection.p: The dissociation between be-selection and past participle agreement is analyzed by Burzio as indicating that past participle agreement is not triggered by the co-indexation between SE and the subject, but rather by the presence of an NP-chain. Accusative SE relies on an NP-movement chain, but dative SE does not (Burzio 1986: 406).

p.span: 11 Burzio (1986) shows that dative SE cannot be subsumed under the unaccusative analysis, but functions instead as an object clitic.

12 According to Burzio (1986), middle-passive SE is not an unaccusativity marker, but rather a particular type of subject clitic. Evidence against this view will be presented in sections 3.4 and 4 below.

13 Zubizarreta's (1987) proposal is a mixed lexicalist-syntactic approach, according to which SE is a verbal operator that is inserted either at L-R (the lexico-syntactic level of lexical representation, to be kept distinct from the lexico-semantic level, notated S-R) or at S-structure, which would result in middle and reflexive interpretations, respectively. Although Zubizarreta herself assimilates SE to A′-operators, this hypothesis does not seem to play any role in her approach, and in fact her notion of ‘verbal operator’ seems closer to that of voice-marker or argument-change marker.

14 Note that given the unergative analysis of SE-reflexives advocated by Reinhart and Siloni (2004), the representations in (19a) and (19a′) should be viewed as pertaining to a level of representation other than S-structure.

15 The particular choice that predicates make between (19a) and (19b) is a matter of lexical semantics: some verbs may take the option in (19a), others the one in (19b) and yet other verbs may allow either option (cf. aimer ‘love’, casser ‘break’, and laver ‘wash’, respectively).
16 Note that French il-impersonals do not rely on the chain configuration in (19b):

row.entry: IL SE HAS translated three novels

subsection.p: Dobrovie-Sorin (1994b, 1998) suggests that a chain of the type in (19b) is formed at LF, after expletive replacement (required by Chomsky's 1986a Full Interpretation Principle) by the raised DP.

p.span: 17 Dobrovie-Sorin (1998) suggests that her characterization of SE can be restated in reflexivity terms (Reinhart and Reuland 1993). SE can be assumed to be a reflexive marker if the definition of reflexive predicates is changed: a reflexive predicate would be one in which two argument positions (rather than two theta-roles) are co-indexed. This suggestion is, however, problematic, because the notions of reflexive marker and reflexive predicate are designed in such a way that they are distinct from ‘simplex expression anaphors’ such as zich. Now, although SE differs from zich in being unable to be long-distance bound, it resembles zich insofar as both SE and zich can be markers of ‘inherent reflexivity’ (in Everaert's 1986b terms) or ‘unaccusativity’, unlike zichself. A careful rethinking of the properties of SE in terms of reflexivity theory remains to be developed.
18 We will leave aside the ‘intensifying’ use of dative SE, which is found in colloquial Spanish:

row.entry: Juan se baila tangos, rumbas, chotis: lo que sea.
John SE dances tangos, rumbas, chotis: whatever there is
Juan se escribe cien versos al dia.
John SE writes (one) hundred verses a day

subsection.p: This type of SE is subject to a syntactic constraint that also holds for benefactives: it can be used only if a direct object is present.

p.span: 19 Note, however, that (the trace of) îşi cannot be bound by the subject of raising verbs:

row.entry: Copiii tǎi îşi pǎreau sǎ fie ferici tcedil;i.
your children SEdat seemed that [they] be happy

subsection.p: This ungrammaticality might be due to a different constraint: a reflexive dative and its antecedent must be co-arguments.

p.span: 20 The Romanian data are somewhat complex, due to the use of prepositional accusatives and clitic doubling, which are both obligatory for proper names. These phenomena are irrelevant here.
21 The correlation between being a pro-drop language and having nominative SE was suggested by Belletti (1982). This correlation holds for French but not for Romanian.

22 The German example in (41) has a generic reading, whereas the Romanian examples in (40) refer to particular events. Note, however, that the impossibility of particular time reference is not peculiar to the sich that combines with unergatives, but characterizes the passivizing use of sich in general:

row.entry: this book HAS SICH yesterday read
this book reads SICH with pleasure

p.span: 23 A conceptually similar analysis can be found in Perlmutter (1978), who argues against the spontaneous demotion of the Agent and proposes instead that impersonal passives rely on the advancement of a dummy, an operation that is the relational grammar counterpart of the NP-movement of a null object in GB theory.

24 Under this view, unergatives do not differ from transitives by their subcategorization properties (both types of verbs may, but are not obliged to, take a direct object), but only by their selectional requirements: unergatives select a cognate object, which as such need not be projected in the syntax, whereas transitives normally select fully referential objects, which must be syntactically realized; some transitives can be construed as having prototypical objects (e.g., eat, drink, write, etc.), which are not lexicalized; those transitives that do not allow for prototypical objects must lexicalize their object (e.g., observe, consider, discover, etc.). In sum, the borderline between unergatives and transitives is less clear cut than is usually assumed, which explains why this distinction is not grammaticalized in well-described languages (compare the be/have alternation that distinguishes unaccusatives on the one hand from transitives and unergatives on the other hand).
25 Dummy null cognate objects may be assumed to be assigned a quasi theta-role (see Dobrovie-Sorin 1998).

26 Depending on the particular definition of passivisation that one may adopt, the reason may be that (i) the ‘absorption’ of accusative Case – which is imposed by passivisation – cannot apply vacuously (Jaeggli 1986a) – in other words, passivisation cannot apply because there is no accusative Case to absorb; or (ii) unaccusatives have no external role, and passivization can apply only if there is an external role to be suspended.

27 Similar contrasts between Romanian and French arise regarding verbs that take idiomatic and sentential complements. The French examples in (iia–c) have the same glosses as the Romanian examples in (ia–c):

row.entry: Li s-a dat apǎ la moarǎ.
to-them SE-HAS given water to the mill
S-a spus/descoperit/declarat cǎ Ion e nebun.
SE-has said/discovered/declared that John is crazy
‘It was said/discovered/declared that John was crazy.’
*Il s’est donné de l’eau à leur moulin.
*Il s’est dit/découvert/déclaré que Jean était irresponsable.

subsection.p: For lack of space we restrict our attention to the contrast concerning unergatives. A detailed discussion of the other data can be found in Dobrovie-Sorin (1994b, chapter 5).

p.span: 28 The reader may have noticed that the examples in (49) are constructed with unergatives that subcategorize a PrepP. With unergatives that do not subcategorize PrepPs, the passive is somewhat less acceptable (the presence of a modifier is obligatory):

row.entry: ?Ensuite, il a été couru jusqu’à la gare.
then, IL was run to the station
?Mais, il a été dormi dans ce lit récemment.
but, IL has been slept in this bed recently

subsection.p: For discussion see Dobrovie-Sorin (1994b).

p.span: 29 Haider (1985b), Haider and Rindler-Schjerve (1987), and Dobrovie-Sorin (1986, 1994b, 1998) are isolated exceptions.

30 French SE-verbs are ambiguous between passive and middle readings. Adverbs such as facilement ‘easily’ are only compatible with the middle reading, which in turn is incompatible with control into a final clause. If facilement is suppressed, the example becomes grammatical, but it loses the middle reading.
31 See also Williams (1985) and Lasnik (1988), who argue that the PRO subject of final clauses need not be controlled by a DP argument, but may be controlled by an event.
32 These examples become grammatical if the embedded verb undergoes SE-passivization:

row.entry: În unele studii s-a încercat a se reface istoria politicǎ şi socialǎ.
in certain essays SE has tried to SE reconstruct the political and social history.
‘In certain essays it was tried for the political and social history to be reconstructed.’
Se sperǎ a se ajunge la capǎtul drumului.
SE hopes to SE arrive at the end of the road
‘It is hoped that the end of the road will be arrived at.’
S-a început a se tcedil;ine seama de nevoile tuturor.
SE-has started to SE take into account everybody's needs
‘It was started that everybody's needs be taken care of.’
S-a promis a se respecta dispozi tcedil;iile.
SE-has promised to SE obey the instructions
‘It was promised that the instructions will be obeyed.’

subsection.p: As indicated by the glosses, both occurrences of SE are interpreted as SE-passives. No ungrammaticality arises, since the verb in the main clause does not function as a control verb: as for any passivized verb, its external argument is suspended and its only argument is the embedded clause itself. We may now wonder why a similar analysis is ruled out for the examples in (54): why is it not possible to analyze the SE in the main clause as an instance of passive SE? The answer is that the embedded verb is in the active form, and as such projects a null subject, which needs to be controlled, a requirement that cannot be satisfied because passive SE cannot function as a legitimate controller. Compare (i–iv), where the embedded clause contains a SE-passive: the external argument has been suspended, thus suspending the need for control.

p.span: 33 Cinque tries to solve this problem by assuming that his [+arg] nominative SE binds a non-referential trace in Spec, IP, which as such is unable to function as a syntactic controller. This peculiarity of [+arg] nominative SE conflicts with the currently observed behavior of nominative clitics, which qualify as syntactic controllers. This is indeed what we find with Cinque's −arg nominative SE, which according to Dobrovie-Sorin (1988) is the only truly nominative SE (see section 4 below).
34 Pronominal clitics exist that are specified for a designated grammatical function (e.g., nominative, dative, or accusative), but not for a particular theta-role.

35 Adopting a suggestion by Chomsky (1986a: 217), Cinque argues that the two chains in (57) are allowed to overlap because they belong to distinct types: one of them is a theta-chain, whereas the other is an expletive–argument pair. One can thus maintain the ban on overlapping theta-chains, while allowing overlapping CHAINs (this notion covers both expletive–argument pairs and theta-chains).

36 This proposal unduly identifies the absorption of the external theta-role by a nominative clitic – which is in fact a particular kind of syntactic realization of the external role, a process that does not suspend accusative Case – with the suspension of the external theta-role by a passivizing morpheme, which blocks the syntactic realization of the external role in the canonical subject position and correlates with the suspension of accusative Case. To make this point clear, consider nominative clitics or even agreeement morphemes. One may assume that they absorb/retain/withhold the external theta-role, but one must ensure that the (Spec, IP) position vacated by nominative clitics/agreement morphemes is not available for a DP that carries the Theme-role (correlatively, accusative Case is available). Otherwise, we would expect nominative clitics, as well as subject-agreement morphemes, to function (at least optionally, but maybe necessarily) as passivizing morphemes, which they do not. In sum, nominative clitics cannot be passivizers because they are syntactic realizations of the external role, which blocks the externalization (encoded as NP-movement in GB theory) of the internal role.

37 Burzio (1986: 144–148) himself observes that French middle-passive se contrasts with Italian nominative si: whereas the latter behaves as a pronominal subject clitic, the former behaves as a lexical affix (cf. inchoative and inherent SE), which as such cannot be affected by subject raising:

row.entry: it SE seems (to) build many buildings

p.span: 38 A detailed review of Cinque's (1988) analysis can be found in Dobrovie-Sorin (1998). Let us simply mention here that Cinque differs from Burzio insofar as Cinque distinguishes between middle and passive SE, which would be marked as accusative and nominative, respectively.
39 Although Burzio (1986) himself is of course fully aware of Restructuring phenomena, he does not subsume examples of si-raising under Restructuring.

40 Mendikoetxa and Battye (1990) assume that nominative and accusative SE head AGRsP and AGRoP, respectively. However, the Spec positions of these projections are not related to SE, since these authors assume that the external role is not absorbed, but merely suspended by SE.

41 The idea that passives involve a null pronoun in Spec, VP is not integral to McGinnis's work on reflexives. In fact, she discarded this idea in later work: McGinnis (1998, 2004) does not treat passives as involving a ‘pro’ external argument.

42 The two authors differ regarding the nature of the empty category controlled/identified by SE (PRO for Kayne and pro for Guéron), as well as regarding the position of this empty category. Both Kayne and Guéron allow the empty category identified by SE to be VP-adjoined, but they disagree on a further possible position: according to Guéron, subject SE binds a pro in a right-hand-generated (Spec, IP) position, whereas Kayne assumes that SE may occupy (Spec, VP). Since for Kayne's views we can only rely on lectures of the 1980s and on a short (1986) abstract, we will concentrate here on the syntactic side of Guéron's (1991) analysis, leaving aside its semantic part, which was not taken up in the subsequent literature on SE.

43 The fact that a dative-marked reflexive does not trigger passivization is clearly indicated by Romanian. Examples such as (i), which contain dative reflexives, can only be interpreted as containing goal or benefactive reflexive pronouns:

row.entry: Ion îşi trimite cǎr tcedil;i poştale.

subsection.p: Conversely, a dative reflexive cannot appear in the Romanian counterparts of French examples of the type in (63):

row.entry: apples-the SEDat eat in [the] the autumn

p.span: 44 There seems to be no reason to believe that in an example such as (i), the Friulan subject clitic al is ambiguous (between the [+arg] and the [−arg] features), whereas in (ii–iii) it is non-ambiguous (being compatible only with the [−arg] feature). The examples are due to Poletto (1991, 1993):

subsection.p: The only plausible analysis is that in all these examples al is a referential clitic. Compare (iv–vi), where al is quasi-argumental or expletive:
It thus seems clear that Cinque's [+arg]/[ −arg] distinction cannot be identified with the well-established distinction between referential and expletive subject clitics.

p.span: 45 Given this analysis, Italian examples of the type SE Vunerg (see (71)) are indeed ambiguous, as suggested by Cinque himself, but the ambiguity is not one between two types of nominative SE but rather one between a nominative SE and a passivizing accusative SE.
46 Cinque's assumption that a nominative passive si exists can be traced back to Burzio's (1986: 48)) proposal, to the effect that certain passive sis bear both accusative and nominative Case.
47 Regarding control into adjunct clauses, see section 3.2 above.

48 Existing analyses of nominative clitics, bearing in particular on Italian dialects, do not provide any counter-example to this generalization, which has, however, not been derived as a consequence of theoretical principles.

49 That overt agreement morphology rather than finiteness is required by nominative SE is clear when one considers Portuguese: it is because this language has infinitivals inflected for AGR features that the Portuguese counterparts of the examples in (64) are grammatical (see Cinque 1988: 531–533).
50 The generalization in (98) has to be qualified in view of some French examples due to Zribi-Hertz (1982):

the issue SE HAS discussed yesterday in the council hall
‘The issue was discussed yesterday in the council hall.’
Le crime s’est commis ce matin.
the crime SE HAS committed this morning
the operation SE HAS carried out yesterday
Le point s’est soulevé hier à la réunion.
the point SE HAS raised yesterday at the meeting
‘The point was raised yesterday at the meeting.’

subsection.p: We will leave these exceptions aside.
